editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MORE WAYS THAN ONE, A COMEDY, AS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN COVENT GARDEN. By MRS. COWLEY.
LONDON: PRINTED BY J. DAVIES, CHANCERY-LANE, FOR T. EVANS, PATERNOSTER-ROW. MDCCLXXXIV.

lg.l: FLY, comic ſcenes! where diſtant Ganges laves
Hindoſtan's golden ſhores, with hallow'd waves;
Where palms gigantic rear their tufted heads,
And nature in coloſſal vegetation ſpreads,
Where rich ananas court the Indian's eye,
And groves of citrons fan the fev'riſh ſky,
Where rattling canes around the riv'lets play,
And the centennial aloe drinks the day!
In their deep ſhades bid Lucidorus ſmile,
His heavy ſenſe of diſtant hours beguile.
Bid him not think, becauſe I gaily write,
That heavy hours to him, to me, are light;
My native ſpirits, bounding from repoſe,
Bear me, unwilling, where Caſtalia flows.
I love to weep, love the ſoft feaſt of grief,
Court mournful thoughts, nor ever wiſh relief;—
Sadneſs I woo, yet ſtill the phantom flies,
And joy ſeduces, whilſt I aſk for ſighs.
But Hymen frowns, and joy no longer cheers,
Weeping, I ſink—Thalia drinks my tears:
He tears my heart; ſhe my rapt ſoul inſpires;
He chills with grief; ſhe fills me with her fires.
Thus, Lucidorus! paſs my diſtant hours—
By turns ſubdued, the ſlave of rival powers;
And thus hath nature in my little frame
Still various been, and variouſly the ſame.
My heart ſo keenly feels, 'twere death to live,
Did not bright ſpirits its ſtrong ſenſe relieve.
Through THESE capricious, deſultory, gay,
As though I felt not, glides th' unconſcious day;
Through THIS I droop, I ſadden, and complain,
Dragging, with penſive ſteps, life's length'ning chain.
In blitheſome mood "More Ways than One" had birth,
Offspring of brilliant morns, and eves of mirth;
The laughing muſe in ſprightlieſt vein was by,
And "quips, and cranks," lay lurking in her eye.
O! may her ſpirit from its pages dart,
Dance o'er your nerves, and live within your heart!

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: SPOKEN BY MR. BONNER, IN THE CHARACTER OF MERCURY.
Enter haſtily from the upper end of the ſtage, as if juſt alighted.

lg.l: SOME eau de luce! Your fans, dear ladies, pray!
Strait from Parnaſſus—'tis a dev'liſh way!
I might have ſtrode our Pegaſus's back,
But the poor devil's grown ſo mere a hack;
So often call'd upon—taught ſuch ſtrange paces,
That alter'd woefully, alack, his caſe is!
In former times, but once or twice a-year
The fiery ſteed was ſummon'd to appear;
Then in elegiac pas grave ſeen dancing,
Or in a comedy-curvet came prancing:
A tragedy each ſpring, a birth-day ode,
Was all his bus'neſs on the Muſe's road:
But now, ſuch hurrying, helter-ſkelter work—
Each cart-horſe moves with a genteeler jirk;
So—in a word, your patience not t' abuſe,
We've ſent our Pegaſus to learn of Hughes.
My buſineſs here?—Plainly and flatly this—
To beg your Honours not to frown or hiſs.
Thalia ſent me, and it makes me ſad,
For "entre nous, (ſays I) the thing is bad."
"Tut, fool!" the Muſe replies—"this powder take,
"Long I've reſerv'd it for a laſt dear ſtake—
"This powder take—dear Mercury, be quick"—
Here 'tis—a mighty ſpell, in this ſlim ſtick.
Scarce had ſhe left me, when Melpomé came—
"Jove's Meſſenger, (ſays ſhe) I'm in a flame!
"I know where Thal' has ſent you—never ſham it,
"But bribe 'em, God of Thieves! bribe 'em to damn it!"
"No, Madam, damn me, if I do!" I cry'd—
She aim'd a blow, I bow'd, and hither hied.
Now for my ſpell—
lg.stage: [Blows ſome powder out of his caduceus.
lg.l: There 'tis—I ſee it ſpread!
'Tis felt in ev'ry heart—in ev'ry head!
Now ſhall you fancy character and wit;
Taſte in the boxes, humour in the pit.
You'll fancy, friends, that 'tis ſo droll and funny—
And you, that you've ſome ſubſtance for your money:
But ſhould the charm diſſolve e'er the play ends,
Oh! for Thalia's ſake, be yet its friends!

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter DAVID, preceded by a Lawyer' Clerk.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: HAS your maſter breakfaſted?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Preakfaſted?—Yes, Sir! Though we live at the court end of the town, we have prought up all our Welch cuſtoms. Our maſter hates Lonton manners, and Lonton laties. What is your puſineſs, goot Sir!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: A buſineſs he will probably like, though it may concern a London lady. Acquaint him that the writings are engroſs'd, and that I have brought them, to fill up the blanks, and ſign.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes, Sir;—pleaſe to ſit, Sir [going]. The writings impoſs'd, and the planks to—What was it, Sir? I muſt have it wort for wort, for my maſter is as exact as Shrewſpury clock.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Acquaint him, friend, that the writings—the marriage articles, are ready. I have brought them from Counſellor Bouquet's, to inſert the names, and ſign and ſeal.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Now, in the faſhionable courſe of things, how long may it be before I ſhall draw up the articles of ſeparation for this young couple? It ſometimes falls out for the good of the profeſſion, that the happy pair ſee but one Chriſtmas together. Nay, I have more than once in my time, engroſs'd the articles of marriage and ſeparation with the ſame gooſe quill.

So, here comes the father of the bridegroom, to pore over the writings, I ſuppoſe. Come, good, wary Sir; if you don't quicken your motions, the young gentleman will excuſe your cares;—every movement of that cane ſpeaks a week's delay.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Tell Miſs Archer to come to me by-and-by. So, Mr. Gooſe-quill—what—a—are they quite ready?

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Quite ready, Sir;—the names only are wanting.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, you may add the names in the next room; but I ſhan't ſign 'till I have look'd your parchments cantiouſly over. No loop-holes for cavils—no expreſſions that will bear ingenious explanations. Defend me from the ingenuity of lawyers!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: You will find all clear, Sir. What are the names?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: That of the lady is Arabella Melville;—mine you know.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; it is Evergreen; but the gentleman's—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: The gentleman's!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—your ſon's—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My ſon's!!—my ſon's!!

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I know it is Evergreen, junior; but the Chriſtian name. I am ſorry to be troubleſome; John, Charles—Sir? Henry? George?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, thou pen-cutter! art thou come to inſult me? My ſon! Evergreen, junior! Why, Sir, I am Evergreen, junior, minor, and major; there is but one Evergreen in the world, and I am he.

sp.speaker: CLERK.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly crave pardon. Are you then the bridegroom?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Timothy Evergreen, Eſquire, of Rook Hall, in the County of Salop. The bridegroom—aye, to be ſure I am. Go, Mr. Feathertip, and leave the blanks as they are—I can fill them up.— [Exit Clerk.] Didſt ever ſee ſuch a puppy, David?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Never, Sir;—not to know that your Honour was the pride! I am ſure one ſhan't ſee a livelier, puxomer pride in all—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Pride! Bridegroom—Taffy!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Got a mercy, Sir! Well, then, the pridegroom; and as for the pridegroomeſs, ſhe is the ſweeteſt, moſt innocent, modeſteſt—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I know how to chooſe.—Did you tell my young plague, Miſs Archer, to come to me?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: I tit inteet, Sir; and ſhe bit me carry my Welch face town ſtairs again in a minute; for that it always made her preakfaſt ſit uneaſy.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, thoſe women who have fine fortunes, and fine lovers, think they have a right to inſult all the world.—She can't ſpare even me—me, who am her natural guardian, and fifteenth couſin.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Laws, Sir, ſhe makes no more of you than if you were an olt woman, inſteat of an antient ſhentleman.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: An antient gent—Oh! in point of family, you mean. Yes, yes,—but this is the laſt day of her triumph here; I would'nt have her another week in my houſe, if—

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Huſh, Sir! here ſhe comes;—and her eyes full of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Where is my guardian—Oh, my ſweet guardian!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Sweet me, no ſweets! I have ſent five meſſages to your Ladyſhip this morning, ere I could have the honor of an interview.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My wiſe Guardian, then: it was to prepare you a preſent, my wiſe guardian, that I ſtaid—a marriage preſent!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: A preſent, hey! What is it? what is it?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: You are to be married in a day or two, I find, to a young and beautiful girl—it is a preſent ſuited to ſuch a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Let me ſee it!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Shut your eyes then.

div.stage: [She goes behind him, and puts on a fool's cap with bells.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What the devil is it? a wedding nightcap?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, a night and day cap—'tis yours for ever.

div.stage: [Holding his hands, whilſt he ſhakes his head to get rid of it.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I'll teach thee to laugh, Taffy, in a moment. Let go my hands. Take it off, Taf! or I'll make thy ſides ſhake to another tune.

div.stage: [David ſnatches the cap, and runs off.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Now, are you not a moſt ungrateful guardian, to ſlight my gifts?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Miſs Archer!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Young woman, you muſt attend to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Young man, I will.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I am, as you ſay, to be married in a day or two.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: David! bring back the cap.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I have told you theſe ſix months to provide yourſelf with another home;—you now have but ſix hours to do it in.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Becauſe I would not have my young innocent wife infected by your manners.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My manners, Sir—What better fate could happen to her? Is ſhe pretty?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: As a young cherub.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Then I'll teach her to captivate the whole town. Why, I, Sir—I am not ſo handſome—that is, not ſo extremely handſome; yet, with my manners, I am every where the object.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: But ſhe ſhall be an object no where.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCH.
sp.p:
But ſhe ſhall; I'll carry her with me all over the world; I'll teach her the equeſtrian bow
in Hyde Park, and how to dart through the croud in the coffee-room at the Opera. She ſhall learn—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: She ſhall learn, that, of all her miſchievous hoity-toity ſex, you are the laſt ſhe is to know; and I'll diſmiſs every ſervant, that ſhe may never hear your name.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I'll be her bridemaid, and, before ſhe has been your wife ſix hours, give her more longings for laces, diamonds, feathers, and fops, than can be gratified in ſix years.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Huh!—h! Why the devil do you not marry yourſelf, and plague ſome other man. You have fools enough to chooſe from—Marry! you have my conſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: But I want that of a much more important perſonage.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Whoſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My own. I ſhall not give up the right of making conqueſts yet;—when my time comes to retire from the ſcene of action, I'll pick out the moſt conſtant of my adorers, go gravely with him to church, drive ſoberly to the ſeat of his anceſtors, grow a dutiful wiſe, ſtudy family receipts and made wines; and when I have the honor of ſeeing your young widow with her new huſband, we'll drink to your memory in a cup of cowſlip of my own brewing

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Seek new lodgings, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I ſhall not, indeed, Sir!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My houſe is my own, Madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
And my guardian is my own, Sir! [imitating.] Are you not my own dear, ſweet guardian,
and are you not going to have a ſweet wife, and to be a ſweet ſimpleton, at the ſweet age of ſixty? Oh, my ſweet, poor—poor, dear guardian! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Drink to my memory in wine of her own brewing!—I'll bribe ſome diſbanded Enſign to carry her off, and make her glad to drink ſmall beer of her own brewing.

div.stage: Enter SERVANT, looking at a liſt.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Let me ſee—one, two, three, four. Well, four new ones every morning, conſidering the ſeaſon has unhappily proved ſo healthy, would do pretty well. I muſt call the doctor—'tis time he was out of his ſtudy,—oh, here he comes,—ſeemingly in a paſſion.

div.stage: Enter FEELOVE from the Flat, with ſeveral printed Bills in his Hand.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are the nation about? What are the parliament about? Is this to be borne?—Here's a collection!—Every morning an inundation of new quacks. Here's a fellow cures the gout by injecting volatiles thro' your ear;—here's another freezes a fever by artificial ſnow, which he produces from the congealed perſpiration of the patient;—and this, purifies the blood from all diſorders, by the ſmell of muſhroom juice, philoſophically prepared. Why, what is to become of the regular practitioner, if theſe fellows are ſuffered to go on? What, I ſay, are the parliament about?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Conſidering, Sir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Conſidering! tax 'em! tax 'em!—The quacks ſhall be taxed. Have I been ſent for to any new patients to-day?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; lady Juniper's dropſy has become troubleſome again—ſhe expects you at eleven. Mr. Calipaſh has a ſurfeit fever, and Mrs. Langriſh hopes you'll call in the courſe of the morning.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Mr. Calipaſh a ſurfeit fever—hum! with the help of bark and aromatics, it may be prolonged three weeks, without injury to the patient.—As to old lady Juniper, frequent viſits will be uſeful,—for in one tapping more ſhe'll come to the dregs; and for my friend, Mrs. Langriſh, if I can't prevail on her to prate leſs, ſhe won't laſt me another ſpring.—That woman will talk two hours without breathing, to deſcribe the effects of an emetic; and, if I did not lower her now and then by a gentle cathartic, ſhe'd evaporate through the lingual organs, like air through a cracked bladder.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I had like to have forgot—Mr. Bellair is coming, Sir!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Coming! No, poor young fellow, he's going—he's going! there! there's the end of the life of a man of pleaſure—it muſt be very unpleaſant to be a man of pleaſure. Nothing could ever prevail on me to be a man of pleaſure.—Oh the temptations that I have withſtood, from black eyes and grey, from tall and ſhort!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I have often thought, Sir,—with ſubmiſſion—that the gentlemen of the wig go through more temptations than people are aware of.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, aye,—there are Joſephs in the faculty, I can promiſe ye. Oh! the white hands that I have ſeen put out between the ſarcenet curtains, with pulſe diſordered only by too much health! Oh the bright eyes that I have ſeen on ſnowy pillows! Oh the—but come, the faculty's great faculty is that of keeping ſecrets—I ſay no more. Did Mr. Bellair crawl up ſtairs laſt night?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: No, Sir; I could not perſuade him, when he found Miſs Arabella was alone.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, he abhors women now—the ſight of a young woman throws him into a catalepſy. I have ſeen him faint only at the touch of Arabella's hand, when ſhe has been chaffing his temples with ſpirits of hartſhorn.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. I have ſometimes thought he had been bit by ſome mad woman, and ſo had a ſort of hydrophobia towards the ſex. Here's ſomebody coming.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Ah! I ſee who it is—you may go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Good morning t'ye Doctor! Doctor Feelove, good morning! How are your pulſe to day?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pho! a phyſician never thinks about his pulſe, any more than a lawyer about his conſcience; the pocket of the one, and the conſtitution of the other, both improve by the neglect.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Then why d'ye feel your patient's pulſe?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: One can't do leſs for a guinea.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, here are the parchments, [taking them from his boſom] here they are! Nothing but names wanting, and ſums.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Names, and ſums, why are they wanting?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, that one may be clear. Your niece has thirty thouſand pounds; and you agree that ſhe ſhall be mine on paying you one-third for your conſent.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: One half.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No,—one-third. I am ſure ten thouſand pounds for a ſimple aye is very well; we know a place, where they'd ſay aye for half the money.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Come, don't libel your betters, till you are poor, and want a penſion. As to our affair, conſider every thing. You know I boarded Arabella, with two ſiſters, at a village in Cornwall, who could teach her nothing but her ſampler; the ſole employment of her life, for ſixteen years, has been her needle, with the occaſional reliefs of making ſeed-cake, and ſtewing codlings.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I know all that—I know all that.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, you know, but you don't draw the inference. Let me tell you that a girl who can't write, who never heard of Point or Bruſſels; whoſe only game at cards is beggar my neighbour; and who thinks the Play-houſe, Ranelagh, and Vauxhall, the three great turnpikes to the devil, is a better fortune with fifteen, than a town bred miſs with thirty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, well, 'tis in vain to argue. Here take the parchments,—fill up the blanks, and write your name. Shall I ſee my little Bell?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: To be ſure. Call down my Niece. Tell her my Lord Penmanmeaur is here.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How ſhall we manage when ſhe finds that I am not a lord, and that ſhe will not be a ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
Pho! that's eaſily managed with ſuch
a novice. Tell her that a peerage, like the parliament, laſts but ſeven years, and that your time is up. Here ſhe comes! ſo, Arabella, here's his lordſhip.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: My pretty Bell, my pretty Bell! why ſo ſad?—on the verge of riding under your own coronet,—why ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I am always ſad, I think. They told me, when I left Cornwall, I was coming to London to be very happy, but indeed I was happier there. In the mornings I rambled in the woods, and uſed to liſten to the ſweet birds till they made me weep;—in the evenings I walk'd by moonlight.—Oh! how I love moonlight walks! with the diſtant village ſounds dying on the ear, till, like the ſoft ſhades of the flowers, they could hardly be diſtinguiſh'd.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, you may have moon-light in London, when it is not foggy; and ſounds of all ſorts.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: But my uncle never ſuffers me to ſtir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, to be ſure—not till you are married.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, nor then neither, without your huſband.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Nor then neither! why they tell me, but I don't care about it, that when I am married I muſt pay viſits, and receive company, and ride in Hyde Park, and be always in public, without once thinking of my huſband.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [apart Doctor! five thouſand muſt be added for that.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Why, how now, huſſey!—who has been putting theſe wicked notions into your head?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why, ſure they can't be wicked, for the Rector's wife and daughters over the way do ſo; and go out in fine carriages, and have cards on Sundays.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Huſſey! huſſey! that's a Biſhop's family—a pariſh prieſt dared not be ſo wicked for his ears.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Come, doctor, don't be ſo harſh—my little pet will be a good girl. I have convinced her that ſhe was made on purpoſe to be my wife; and that it will be the duty of my wife to hate gadding, and particularly to hate all young fellows.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No—you ſaid particularly thoſe with cockades and gorgets.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Did I?—then I was too ſlack. They are all the ſame—the gorgeted, the ſcarf'd, the broad bands, and the narrow bands; if they are young, you muſt hate them all—and if they preſume to talk nonſenſe to you, make me your ſecret keeper, and then I ſhall be able to hold you up, as the exact model of a perfect wife.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, and, like other models, it will be very badly copied. But pray, miſtreſs, in this pretty leſſon of your's, where do you find any thing about your viſitings, and gadding about, in the libertine ſtile you were juſt now ſpeaking of?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, no;—no modeſt woman receives viſits from any but relations; nor, amongſt thoſe, from none of a remoter degree than uncles and aunts.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What, not a Couſin?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Not if it's a male couſin.—Oh horrid! a male couſin in the family of a young married woman is a worſe monſter than a man-tiger.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: But Mr. Bellair is not my Couſin,—ſo I may let him come without any harm:—Oh! how I ſhall like to ſupport his poor aching head on my boſom; and, when he is fainting, to give him cordials, and weep over him till he recovers.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are you ſaying, Arabella?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I was only conning my leſſon, Sir; that part of it is ſo pretty, that, whenever I think on it, I ſigh, and feel ſo melancholy!—and yet 'tis a melancholy ſweeter than all the pleaſure I have ever taſted.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, go, go! that's my pretty Bell; get it all into your head, and never fear but it will influence your actions.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I muſt leave ye, or my patients will be impatient.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall ſee you again in the evening; meantime look over the parchments.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I will. Why, now I have been a fool; I have made the bargain more favourable on his ſide than I needed. I really believe he would have taken her with the ten thouſand only. I'll try to ſtart ſome difficulty in the buſineſs.—I hate to be over-reach'd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
More Ways than One indeed! and your way is moſt ſingular! imported with you, I ſuppoſe, from Leyden.—Aſſume ſickneſs to captivate a blooming
girl! ſuch a way of love-making could never have occur'd but in a college.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My ſickneſs was aſſumed not to captivate, but to get introduced to her. You have often heard that pity is ſiſter to love, and I have proved it ſo, in the heart of the gentle Arabella.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, ſpeaking to BELLAIR.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Your ſervant has been here, Sir, to ſay that Doctor Feelove requeſts you not to call till one, as he is obliged to make a wide circuit this morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Very well. Bid him let my wrapping gown be ready, with my pale complexion, and all other neceſſaries. [Exit ſervant] I muſt have a wider gown; in that I am not ſufficiently ſcreen'd; who, but a Doctor, could believe that theſe limbs belong to a fellow in the laſt ſtage of an atrophy.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, they are ſo uſed to wonders, you may make them believe any thing; but have you never yet found a moment to convince the Lady, that you have as much health and aſſurance as any man in town?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never,—nor do I know that I yet wiſh it, for I ſhould then loſe the luxury of her tender aſſiſtances, the ſoft preſſure of her hand, and the tear dropping from her blue eye on my cheek, whilſt ſhe believes me in a ſtate of inſenſibility—How can I bear to give up all that?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Then to hear her ſigh, and aſk her uncle, in the teadereſt accents, "if nothing can be done for me?" I ſwear, a direct avowal of her paſſion would not give me ſuch tranſport. How charming! to witneſs nature's
genuine feelings in a beautiful girl, inſtead of thoſe factitious ones impos'd by education.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Her mode of education has been ſtrange, ſure! do you find nothing repulſive in it?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Repulſive! quite the reverſe—it has a thouſand charms for me. Her mind is naturally ſo elegant and ingenuous, that the taſk of poliſhing it can be but ſlight, and that charming taſk will be mine! I ſhall be her enamour'd Abelard!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is it ſo very charming to be a ſchool-maſter?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a phraſe! [impatiently] To unite the characters of lover and inſtructor, ſeems to me the moſt intereſting of human ſituations.

q.l: "What joy to wind along the cool retreat,
"To ſtop, and gaze on Delia as I go;
"To mingle ſweet diſcourſe with kiſſes ſweet,
"And teach my lovely ſcholar all I know!"

sp.p: So ſung, you know, one of our firſt poets.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: One of our firſt poets is very welcome to have ſung, or ſaid it. But give me a woman whoſe ſoul is all inform'd, and alive to every enjoyment of taſte and feeling! I would rather my wife ſhould join in converſation with grace, than ſhrink from it, overpowered by her bluſhes; and that ſhe ſhould make the men afraid of her wit, rather than allure them by her ſimplicity.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You ſpeak as though you knew ſuch a woman?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Perhaps I may—but of that hereafter.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Hereafter be it then, for now I am impatient to be gone. I muſt practiſe an hour, before I
ſhall reduce my pipe to the ſhrill tone ſuited to my appearance;—you would not inſure my life three days, if you ſhould ſee me when metamorphoſed.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nor your underſtanding for three hours, now that I know the cauſe of it—but adieu! in a week you'll be recover'd.

div.stage: ARABELLA ſitting at a Table, with Paper and Pencil.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: No, that won't do [taking up a ſlip of paper]—Yes it will—no! it is not half ſo ſoft and pretty. [retouches it] There now! that little touch at the corner of the mouth has made it clear another thing. Oh, how happy thoſe ladies are that can draw!—if I could draw, I'd make his ſweet face ſo white; and his eye ſhould be juſt lifted up to me, as it is ſometimes; and between his lips I would ſee a little bit of his white teeth, and—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Heyday! what is ſhe about! [peeping] What now, Arabella! writing?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, no; you know I can't write—I wiſh I could.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
Wiſh you could! why? to enlarge your ſphere of miſchief? pity there's a gooſe-quill in the kingdom, except thoſe in the hands of the faculty, the clergy, and the law;—though, as to the law, I believe, there would be no great harm, if their's were
taken away too. But what uſe, pray, would you make of a pen?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, I'd write—I'd write down a ſong that I have been making out of my own head, but I can't finiſh it, becauſe I can't write. It begins—
sp.l: Soft are my gentle Jockey's looks,

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: "Lily pale his face."—Aye, that moſt young men can boaſt of—roſy cheeks are as ſcarce now in England, as roſe buſhes in Scotland. Let me ſee that paper—what's this? a flower pot?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No, it's Jockey. [very artleſly.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Jockey! why thou haſt a good pretty notion, girl, enough!—ſome fancy there—it might take a man a good while to explain it. But come, [throwing down the paper, which ſhe picks up, and puts in her boſom.] I want to talk to you a little. Here will be the poor young man preſently—Mr. Bellair.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear, will be? [joyfully.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Now you know he's dying.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Is he. [ſadly.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Therefore we muſt make hay while the ſun ſhines.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: The ſun won't ſhine, when he dies. [aſide.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: He has a good fortune, and neither chick nor child. He muſt leave it to ſomebody you know, and moſt likely it will be to thoſe who are moſt kind to him; now I would have you ſhew every kind of decent civility to him, that a modeſt young woman may ſhew.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
I am ſure I always do. I would lay down my life to bate his pains; ſometimes they are very bad,
and then he graſps my hand ſo hard!—but I am not angry with him.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, to be ſure; he is ſick, poor man—if he was well 'twould be quite another thing—never let a man in health preſs your hand. But, as I was ſaying, I have no doubt but his gratitude will ſecure us ſome acknowledgement at his death.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, dear uncle! you had better ſecure an acknowledgement for ſaving his life.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, but when people's lives are ſaved, they ſeldom think of an acknowledgement;—if you can get into a ſick man's will, 'tis ſafer to let him go.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mr. Bellair is coming up, Sir.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Oh, let me aſſiſt him. [runs out] Stay, good Sir!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, dear, how weak he is! [looking through the wing.] But I declare he is not ſo pale—no not half ſo pale as he was. Oh! how I ſhould love my uncle if he would recover him—I'd give all I have in the world!

div.stage: Enter BELLAIR, ſupported by FEELOVE, and the SERVANT.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Lean on me, good Mr. Bellair, lean harder! come, think me your nurſe, as well as your Doctor—you know we rank with old women.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [Panting] You, are kind—hooh! very kind. Your ſtairs—hooh! have exhauſted too much of my waſting breath.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all our breaths are waſting; but come, take courage—you may have more years before ye, than I have yet, perhaps.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, I gueſs I may; or Nature will play me a ſlippery trick. [aſide.] Pray ſupport me to that ſopha. [advances a ſtep or two, then ſtops ſhort.] That young woman there again! Oh, Doctor! do you not know how baneful to me, is the ſight of a young woman?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, how can he hate me ſo? it will break my heart. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, my niece is uſeful in the room; you are ſometimes apt to be faintiſh, and maid-ſervants are ſo unhandy—But if ſhe offends you, ſhe ſhall go.—Go, Arabella.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Well, I can ſtay at the door, and ſee him through the crevice—Sure that can't offend him!— [penſively.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, let her ſtay—let her ſtay! Going out of the world, as I am, it is my duty to conquer averſions. I will even let her ſit by me—Sit down, young lady!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Where are your drops, Arry?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Here they be.

div.stage: [She takes them from her pocket; he ſeizes the bottle and her hand together.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Don't take too much of 'em, Sir—don't keep them too long at your noſe.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, they revive me beyond expreſſion!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, they are very good drops. Dear, how tight he holds my hand! [aſide.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My ſpirits are very low; and I have odd fancies, Doctor—very odd fancies!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but you ſhould always oppoſe odd fancies. I knew an old lady, who fancied herſelf purſued by Death—She ſwore he ſhould not have her, and actually contended with the phantaſm ſo long, that ſhe vanquiſhed him. That very obſtinacy which ſent three huſbands out of the world, kept her in it, contrary to the predictions of the wiſeſt heads in Warwicklane.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But I have a ſtranger fancy than that, Doctor.—I have a fancy that I ſhall live, and be ſome day or other a hale, ſtout young fellow.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: [aſide.] That's a ſtrange fancy, indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And that many beings may yet owe life to me.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I have no doubt of it, Sir . . . . . Beings of the reptile kind.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir, here is a gentlewoman, very earneſt to conſult you.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I'll be with her in a moment. Will you give me leave?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Go, go, good Doctor, I will try to recover myſelf, to tell you my new ſymptoms, when you return.—But pray don't hurry the gentlewoman.

div.stage: [Exit FEELOVE. BELLAIR turns and gazes on ARABELLA.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, angel!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Is he going to pray? how fiery his eyes look! [aſide.] . . . . . . Pray, Sir, quiet yourſelf; reſt your head a little on me—I fancy it is in pain.

div.stage: [He reſts his head on her ſhoulder, with his arm round her.]

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Epicures and voluptuaries!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: He talks Latin! they ſay people do ſo, when they are poſſeſs'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, this is too much! [lifting his head.] I will declare myſelf at once.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear Sir, if you have any ſins upon your mind, the ſooner you declare them the better—it may make your conſcience eaſy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, I will declare—Oh, moſt enchanting—

div.stage: [drops on one knee; Feelove enters, and he lets himſelf fall on the floor.]

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Bleſs me, he is fainting!—aye, he is far gone indeed, poor man!—Very odd! [taking his hand.] His pulſe is good, though he is ſo bad.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: When he fell he was going to declare ſome crime to me—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Some crime!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, and it ſeemed to overpower his conſcience ſo, the moment he began to ſpeak, that he could not bear it.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, he has been but bad, I doubt, but now he pays for all. Come, Sir, cheer ye, cheer ye! [helping him up.] I won't leave ye again; I'll ſit by ye, if its an hour;—the very ſight of a Doctor is better, ſometimes, than phyſic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are very kind! but I believe I ſhall not be the better for you now. In the afternoon, if you'll permit me, I ſhall call again.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I'll go to you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Not for the world!—I give you too much
trouble. The air of this part of the town, ſo near the Park, revives me—Permit me to come as often as I can; I hope I ſhall not be long in this ſad way. Pray, Doctor!

div.stage: [putting a bank note in his hand.]

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, it is needleſs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The young lady's drops are very good. About ſix I'll be here again—you'll let her be in the way.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That ſhe ſhall. Come, Sir, lean on me.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear, how he looks at me! it thrills my boſom through and through! Sure he can have no very great crime on his mind—I am ſure he never can have been wicked—I'll endeavour to comfort him when he comes again. Meantime, I'll go into my own room, and try to finiſh this. [taking the paper from her boſom.] I think I can make it look a little as he did juſt now,—and then—then, if he dies— [dropping a tear.] I can look at this, and think of him!

div.stage: Enter CARLTON, followed by BELLAIR in a Chair.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [to the Chairman.] Stop—ſtop! Carlton!— [gets out of the chair, and throws in his gown.] There! carry it home, and call for me at ſix.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, oh! what return'd from the Doctor's?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This moment left the houſe;—this moment left—Oh, Carlton!—I ſhall be there again at ſix—My time will hang on my hands till then—how ſhall I kill the heavy hours?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
If you really want to murder them, go
home, and ſend for a dozen of the reforming reports: if you want only to forget them, go with me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: To call on Sir Marvel Muſhroom. I pay him a viſit once in ſix months, ſtay ſix minutes; and laugh, after I have left him, ſix hours.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Who the devil is this Sir Marvel, who is ſuch a ſpecific for ennui?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Been in London a month, and not know Sir Marvel! Why, Sir Marvel was the other day a grocer, or an ironmonger, or a cheeſemonger, I don't remember which—near one of the city gates, I don't remember where.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What is he now?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Now! a man of figure, Sir—a man of expence. To be ſeen every morning in Hyde Park, on a little Galloway, followed by two ſervants on a brace of hunters. Every noon in a phaeton, making the circuit of St. James's-ſtreet, Pall Mall, and the Hay Market; and every night, in every place where a ticket or effrontery can admit him.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, but where's the peculiarity of all this?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, all that's nothing—the captivating part of the Knight is to come. At the youthful age of forty ſome relation left him a large eſtate:—He threw off his apron, drove to his domains in a poſt chaiſe and ſix, roaſted bullocks, broach'd hogſheads, &c. &c. was next year ſheriff for the county, and carried up an addreſs—This accounts for his title.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
His Honour now found it neceſſary to read, on the penalty of being ſilent wherever he went—to
which his loquacity could not ſubmit. He accordingly buys every author on every ſubject; peruſes poetry, tactics, philoſophy, botany, cookery, agriculture; and, to ſhew that he can read, is for ever quoting.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tireſome enough!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Not at all—as he manages, 'tis moſt pleaſant; for beginning to read ſo late in life, with the advantage of a very bad memory, he makes the happieſt miſtakes imaginable. His head contains an olio of arts and ſciences, ſo mingled and confuſed that he conſtantly ſpeaks of one thing for another; and if Boyle or Clarendon are mention'd, ten to one but he'll give ye an old catch as a ſpecimen of their talents.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: His French valet aſſiſts in furniſhing the inſide of his head, as well as to frize the out, and always gives his maſter the theme for the day.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Precious! this fellow muſt be excellent to kill time with—let us go directly.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: With all my heart—he receives a new acquaintance as eagerly as a new book; and whether you are in calf-ſkin or morocco, it will make no difference to Sir Marvel.

div.stage: [SIR MARVEL at his toilet, attended by LE GOUT, who is powdering his hair with a puff.]

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Depechez, monſieur—depechez! I am impatient.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p:
Ah, monſieur! de Inglis be tous jours ſo, and for dat reaſon dey will never do credit to dere valets. A French general ſpend as much time in taking
de powder in his hair, as in direction de powder to his enemy; and would rader live, dan be found dead in the field of battle ill dreſs.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, but now, you know, monſieur, the French are going to follow us—we are all the go in Paris. Next war I dare ſay your generals will head their armies in buckſkin, and bobwigs; and if they are found dead on the field of battle, it will be with Britiſh balls in their bodies. (ſtarting up) Have done! you have been as long raiſing the ſiege of that curl, as the Goths were in taking Cuba.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Nay den, monſieur, I vill ave done; but pardon me, monſieur! it does uſe me very ill; I vill live vid no maſter who ſo diſgrace me.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Diſgrace you!

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Oui, ſans doute, de diſgrace be mine. De quality will not ſay of you—"Oh, what Burgeois be dat! ah, mon Dieu, quelle bete!" dey will ſay who dreſt dat man? he be as mal adroit as a Flemiſh boor—ſend him a new valet, he be dreſs by a Dutch barber." My reputation be concern'd, monſieur.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why now you know, Le Gout, I take great care of your reputation, and form myſelf entirely on your documents. You have liv'd ſo long with dukes and lords, and noble cricketers, and gentlemen cheſsplayers, that you know the daſh of high life exactly; and if I had a ſon, I would prefer you to any French governor in London.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p:
Oh, as to dat, monſieur, I would not be French governor to any ting. Running about after little maſter—ſitting behind him at de play, and vid my
back to de horſes in de vis-a-vis, and be at de bottom of de table when de chaplain ave leave of abſence;—no, no, ſome French governors dat I know ave taken up de powder puff again, and prefer dere original occupation of valet, to de pleaſure of whipping maſter for von hundred a year, and being tied to his jacket, like de keys to de houſekeeper's girdle.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Well but, monſieur, have you thought of a ſubject for me to day—You can't conceive how brilliant I was at Mrs. Flanconade's yeſterday. She thought to poſe me once, and interrupted me with (ſpeaking in a thick voice.) "Pray, Sir Marvel Muſhroom, at what time was the Roman republic in it's glory?" Very good, ma'am, ſays I—very good! as tho' all the world did not know the republic was in it's greateſt luſtre when Alexander the Great was king at Rome—ha, ha, ha! No conceiving how it was enjoy'd—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Dere monſieur! dere! I be diſgrace again. Why Alexander was never king at Rome, he was king of de Turcs.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You are right, you are right, Monſieur. The dog is clearly wrong, but I dare not contradict him.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A gentleman, whoſe name is Pearlaſh, is below, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Pearlaſh—Pearlaſh! oh, I remember; I knew him laſt year at Brighton. The ſon of a ſoap boiler, Le Gout. What the devil does he want?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: He only ſent up his name, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: His name! why ſurely he does not put himſelf on a viſiting foot. Tell him, I am engag'd at preſent—ſome other time—

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Oh, wrong, Monſieur!—pardon me, quite wrong!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why! ſhould I receive him?

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Sans doute—receive every body. De great people make all dere power dat way. In Groſvenor-ſquare, a citizen fend his name to a lord;—de lord ſhrug his ſhoulders—"damn de greaſy ſoap boiler—ſend him up!" He fly to receive him, catches his hand—"My dear Mr. Pearlaſh, how I am oblige for dis honeur!—where have you been dis age? can I do any ting for you?—make uſe of me—give me de happineſs to ſerve you!"

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Do they condeſcend ſo much?

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Condeſcend!—pſhaw! dat idea is baniſh de world—dere is no condeſcenſion. De canaille is de fountain of riches, derefore de lords treat dem vid reſpect, and tell dem of dere majeſty: in return, de Canaille, burſting vid vanity and gratitude, let de Lords drain dere purſes, and ſo bote ſides reſt ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Enough! Lead the way. [to the Servant.] Le Gout, follow. I'll ſnatch his hand, and outdo a duke in the warmth of my embraces.

div.stage: Enter CARLTON and BELLAIR, with another Servant.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel is juſt gone down to ſome company, Sir.—I'll inform him that you are here.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Was not that the lovely Bab Archer, you bowed to, as we came in?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It was Miſs Archer; but you don't think her handſome?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Critically ſo—perhaps not; but ſhe is more—ſhe is captivating! Her voice is melody; and there is elegant mind in every motion.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Elegant mind, do you call it? I am ſure her's is a moſt inſolent one.—I knew her abroad; and this woman, who in your opinion is made up of melody, ſweetneſs, and witchery, is the moſt perverſe, the moſt capricious, the moſt proud, the—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Tut! tut! that is to ſay, you have been her ſlave, and a neglected one.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Faith, there is hardly a man of your acquaintance who will not ſubſcribe to my opinion of her.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: The ſtrongeſt proof of her charms, and of her power. I adore her for being hated by all the men who have had the preſumption to ſigh for her. There is a degree of impurity in a woman who ſmiles on, and liſtens to, all who chooſe to make love to her. When I marry, my wife muſt bring me an ear as uneſſayed as her heart; and the firſt whiſpers of love that reach her, muſt be from my lips.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, carry your whiſpers to Miſs Archer, kneel, ſigh, weep, and—be deſpiſed!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: At your conceiving that, with a woman of her character, I ſhould purſue ſo beaten a track. No, no; I have reſolv'd to woo her, but it ſhall be by an appearance of indifference. I'll ſet her heart in a blaze by my coldneſs, and conquer her with ſlights.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Why your way of love making is more ſingular than mine; but as to its ſucceſs, I ſhould as ſoon
believe the floating batteries had more effectually been attack'd by ſnow balls, than Elliot's red hot bullets.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A flaming alluſion!—But here comes our Knight. [Enter MARVEL and LE GOUT.] My dear Sir Marvel, Mr. Bellair begs to be known to you.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: My dear Sir, I do not deſerve ſo great an honour. [Embracing Bellair] Can I do any thing for you?—make uſe of me—give me the happineſs to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: LE GOUT.
sp.p: Monſieur—Monſieur! dis is not de way to treat gentlemen. You muſt embrace, and make offers of ſervice, only to de canaille.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Enough! did you come from the country, Mr. Bellair?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: From Leyden.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Leyden! you came from Leyden—ah! I remember, that's the place where they are ſo famous for lead mines.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is no ſtanding this. [to Carlton.] You have good paintings, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, I flatter myſelf I have taſte that way. We have moderns who pretend to paint—ha, ha!—ſave us from modern painters!—the antique is the thing! Now, for a portrait painter, there's nobody like that little droll fellow, Eraſmus; he gave us fleſh and blood to the life!—But for a cabinet piece, give me a Dutch Fair by Scipio Africanus. What is he laughing at? he behaves very oddly!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe him—unhappily ignorant—has read nothing.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
Indeed! I'll offer him my library. My
dear Sir, you'll pardon me; but one can make no figure without reading. In ſuch a place as Leyden, you can have had no opportunities—My library is at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You do me a moſt particular favour, Sir Marvel. Well choſen, I am ſure it muſt be.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, as to that—yes, yes, Sir—aye, Mr. Carlton, you have ſeen my library. All the poets from Mecaenas to Shaftſbury. All the dramatic writers of name—including Shakeſpear, Lycurgus, and Pliny.—Read well, Sir; and after you have read, begin to write.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Write!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, yes; one is not finiſh'd without it—every body writes. One cannot put one's head into company without meeting half a dozen ode-writing miſſes, and matrons who compoſe eſſays—but ſatire is my forte.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What then you write, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Trifles! trifles! There is a thing of mine in the papers to-day. You know, for every body knows, Miſs Archer?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Doubtleſs.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You know ſhe is the moſt haughty, affected creature living; and to-day I gave her in doggerel—mark that—in doggerel; heroic verſe would have been too dignified for the ſubject. There ſhe is, in the poet's corner, at full length.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Satirize Miſs Archer!—ſurely you have not dared.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes I have. Why not ſatirize Miſs Archer? I ſatirize myſelf ſometimes, and anſwer it again the next day.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: By Heaven! on reflection, it pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Beſides, to tell you the truth, there is another reaſon—Now I ſhall ſurpriſe ye, I know;—I hardly expect ye to believe me—but—in ſhort, ſhe has actually refuſed me!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Refuſed you! Nay then, Carlton, you may as well give it up—You'll hardly expect to ſucceed where Sir Marvel has failed.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I don't know that—I don't know that; thoſe capricious women generally chooſe the worſt—You know the proverb—dainty dogs.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Delicate! So 'tis revenge, then—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, revenge—But I ſtill continue to viſit her in a friendly way; for ſhe's faſhionable, and one finds the firſt daſh there: Beſides, I have ſuch good-nature and generoſity about me, that I never can be out of humour with people to their faces.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: In courſe, you don't mean to acknowledge your ſatire. But is it very ſevere?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, tears her like a bramble buſh.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Then do me the favour to give me for the author.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Moſt particularly ſo:—In ſhort, I want to be introduced to her, and I know no better way.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tell her he is dying for her—that's a better way.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Yes, to be made a fool. Will you oblige me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: To be ſure—Gad, I ſhall like ſuch a ſcreen! for I have had the terror of her fingers before my eyes.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Go, then, this inſtant, my dear Sir Marvel; not a moment is to be loſt! Come, Bellair. Let nothing tempt you betray that you are the poet.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Never fear! I am not a gooſe, to betray the Capitol.

div.head: ACT III. An Apartment at EVERGREEN's.

div.stage: Enter Miſs JUVENILE, and a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUVENILE.
sp.p: TELL Miſs Archer I can't ſtay a minute, I have only brought a newſpaper to ſhew her. [exit Serv.] Lud! lud! how this will gall her! I never read ſuch a piece of abuſe in my life.—I wonder how the author got it in! I have wrote twenty pretty things of this ſort myſelf; but ſome wiſe, grave editor or other, always cropt my laurels. The next morning the anſwers to correſpondents never failed to inform them that, "The lines of L. S. were inadmiſſible;" or, "The Epigram ſigned Laura wont do for our Paper;" or "we muſt deſire our fair correſpondent Clariſſa to learn to ſpell, before ſhe pretends to write heroic verſe." I wonder really at their impertinence;—that a young lady of faſhion can't amuſe herſelf in rhyming a little about her friends, but they muſt pretend to judge of the matter!
Oh, my dear Miſs Archer! do you know that ſome cruel wretch here—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, yes, my dear, I know it all; you are the fifteenth lady who has been here this morning, to inform me of it. Upon my word a newſpaper paſquinade is a mighty good thing—it makes one's friends remember one.

sp.speaker: JUV.
sp.p: Deuce take 'em! I thought to have been the firſt,—now I don't know how it touch'd her.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Why do you muſe, my dear?

sp.speaker: JUV.
sp.p: Oh, muſe—why I am muſing upon the wickedneſs of people—to dare—to be able—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, never think about it. I tell you ſuch things are rather a diſtinction—to be abuſed in a newſpaper is to be rank'd with half the amiable and great characters in exiſtence. Hah! here's another viſitant, with another newſpaper! Why my friends are ſo numerous, they'll be oblig'd to put forth another impreſſion before noon. Good morning, Sir Marvel Muſhroom!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, your moſt devoted! Have you heard of this ſcurrilous abuſe?—Oh, yes, you have heard, I ſee;—Miſs Juvenile is here.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: You might have met half your acquaintance here twenty minutes ago, they are kindly gone to diſperſe the papers.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Marvel, can you gueſs at the writer?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, that's not a fair queſtion. What do you think of the lines?

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Pointed to the laſt degree! witty and ſevere!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: A'n't they?—this couplet

div.stage: [They each read alternately, Miſs ARCHER ſtanding between them.]

sp.speaker: MARVEL.
sp.l: "Some forms won't yield to leathern traces."

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.l: "The bluſhes form'd with ſo much art,"

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: "The affected—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Nay, pray, good people! have a little compaſſion!

div.stage: [She claps a hand before each mouth; they ſtruggle to ſpeak, with their eyes fixed on the papers; as ſhe removes her hands, they each ſpeak.]

sp.speaker: MARVEL.
sp.p: —"Clear ſtarcher!"

sp.speaker: Miſs JUVENILE.
sp.p: —"Miſs Archer!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: What d'ye think of it, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: What is your motive for reading it to me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Motive—motive—why 'tis fit every body ſhould know what's ſaid of them. That great philoſopher, Heliogabalus, ſaid the abuſes of his enemies were more ſerviceable to him than the praiſes of his friends.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I am quite of that opinion, and wiſh therefore, to know whom I have to thank for this ſervice.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Do you? would you really wiſh to know him?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, really.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Shall I bring him to you?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Then you know him?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Perfectly well. I will not give his name, but if you have any curioſity, he ſhall receive your thanks in perſon this evening.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I ſhould like it above all things. I have ſpent a life in hearing flatteries and falſehoods—let me for once ſee a man who has the courage to ſpeak what he thinks. Pardon me for leaving you—I ſhall expect you and my panegyriſt at ſeven.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: You ſee ſhe can't ſtand it—ſhe is finely nettled.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſhe feels it.—I am not ſurpriſed at it.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: I wonder what blockhead wrote it! for, between ourſelves, I never read more wretched ſtuff.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Wretched ſtuff!

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Oh, vile! tho' I made her believe I thought it all wit and poignancy.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why really, Miſs Juvenile, I am ſurpriſed that people will give opinions ſo raſhly. Miſs, the perſon who wrote this little morceau is remarkable for his ſkill in belles lettres.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Belles lettres!—ſkill in bell metal might do for ſuch lines as theſe—they might be hammer'd out of any thing.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Very well, ma'am! very well! I muſt beg leave to ſay, that it is not ſo agreeable to hear the talents of one's friends ſlighted.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p:
Indeed! you are mighty liberal;—in general 'tis the moſt agreeable treat a friend can
have. I wiſh you wou'd let me know who this friend is, for whoſe reputation you are in ſuch pain.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: What d'ye think of Mr. Carlton?

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: What do I think? ha, ha, ha!—My dear Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Nay, if you wont believe me, come this evening and ſee him here.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Well, really now, it is ſurpriſing!—I did not think he had poſſeſs'd ſo much ill-nature.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Ill-nature! Let me tell you, Miſs Juvenile, private ill-nature may be a public good. To make people's time paſs happily is very benevolent, and if it was not for a little pleaſant thing of this ſort, now and then in a morning, people's chocolate would be as dull and infipid as the Ve—Venetian black broth.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Spartan, I fancy you mean.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Spart—gad! that's very true; what a ridiculous miſtake!—ha, ha, ha! Thank ye, Miſs—thank ye. Yes, I remember now, the Venetians were thoſe who joined the Macedonians in the war againſt Philip;—how could I make ſuch a miſtake!—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: One may as well be quiet—in trying to help the poor man out, he gets but the deeper in. (aſide). Pray, Sir Marvel, order my chair.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, yes. Venetian!—how could I make ſuch a miſtake?

div.stage: Carlton and Bellair ariſe from a table with glaſſes, &c.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
And ſo you really mean to perſuade the
innocent thing, that running away with Harry Bellair is the moſt honourable ſtep ſhe can take?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At leaſt the happieſt; for does ſhe not love me? What is her fate if ſhe ſtays? She will be huddled, in leſs than three days, into a marriage, with a paſſion in her heart, adding bitterneſs to diſguſt and mortification.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Where would you place her to be in ſafety?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have a friend in town, the gravity of whoſe character will be a ſhield to her's. I have neglected him ſince I came from Leyden, but I'll go and make it up with him this very day. Let that paſs—now to my queſtion; will you aſſiſt in the enlevement?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: If I am not ſummon'd to the adorable Archer. If my ſcheme there takes place—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That's really too abſurd! If ſhe believes you to be the author of that vile abuſe, and invites you, it muſt be to poiſon you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I don't care with what view it is, if I am but invited;—I ſhall be ſure, at leaſt, not to rank with the brilliant captains, the Sir Tommys, and Sir Neddys, who are receiv'd, court'ſey'd to, and forgot.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, you'll certainly be remember'd.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I am convinced that a woman who has been admired all over Europe, and returns with an untouch'd heart, is not to be won by flattery, or by ſtooping to her power. 'Tis pride ſecures her, and her pride muſt be taken down, before Love can find a vulnerable place for his darts.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That will do for a figure—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Aye, and for a reaſon too;—I ſhall govern myſelf by it, however.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: The perſon you ſent for, Sir, is in the parlour.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'll attend him—excuſe me half a moment.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel Muſhroom enquires for you, Sir, he has been at your lodgings, and was directed hither.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Admit him! admit him! [he enters] My dear Sir Marvel, what news from the lady?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I found her as inflammable as one of Montgolfier's balloons. The whole town had been with her—the whole town is mad about my ſatire!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Then 'tis in vain for me to hope for the credit of being it's author—it is not in mortal wight to lend ſo much reputation, for half an hour.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, but you are miſtaken—I diſclaim'd it—diſclaim'd all the glory—and ſhe deſires this evening to ſee the incomparable author.—So you will, Pyramus like, drive, for one day, the chariot of the Sun.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Shall I?—will ſhe ſee me?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: She pants for an interview: the beauteous Helen was not more deſirous of receiving Leander, when he ſwam every night-acroſs the Mediterranean. I have promiſed to carry you this evening. But be ſure you don't give me as the poet, 'till I give the word.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nothing can be farther from my deſign—You ſhall gather your laurels when you pleaſe. I prize this mode of introduction ſo highly, that I know not how to return the favour.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, Lord, nothing can be ſo eaſy. I hear you have a pretty poetical quill, and that you ſometimes write Latin verſes;—publiſh a volume, and call it mine.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I'll conſider it.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: You may throw in a touch of Greek, too. I ſhould learn Greek, for the pleaſure of reading Ovid, but their d—d crooked characters are ſo alike, that one may as well attempt to learn Spaniſh, of Dutch mackerel.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear friend, I am too impatient to give the time I ought to your erudition;—I had rather hold a convention with my taylor and valet than with Ovid and Horace; and had rather this night be as well dreſt as Count Grammont, than as well read as Doctor Johnſon.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Hah, my dear Mr. Bellair! Will you excuſe me; I can't ſtay—I came to call on Mr. Carlton. I have done his buſineſs for him—He's going to viſit the lady, and he ſwears he'll be as well dreſt as Doctor Johnſon.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you know your buſineſs. You are to go to Mr. Feelove's, and tell him—But ſtay, can you weep on occaſion?

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, I don't doubt but I can ſqueeze a tear, upon a pinch.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, ſqueeze as many as you can; and tell him that your wife is in extremity at Hampſtead, and deſires his immediate aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: My wife!—then I'd better not cry, Sir; it won't ſeem ſo natural.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Well, manage that as you will.—Here is ſomething for your ingenuity—Be ſure, at all events you ſee the Doctor into his chariot, and give him a direction to ſome houſe in Hampſtead.

sp.speaker: STRANG.
sp.p: Never fear me—I humbly thank ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: So! having made a clear road for the Doctor, I can fearleſly purſue my own. My ſweet Arabella! in ten minutes I'll be at thy feet.

div.stage: [EVERGREEN aſleep on a ſopha, ARABELLA ſitting at work, on a chair. After looking on him, ſhe riſes.]

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, how different it ſeems when Mr. Bellair is on that ſopha! I could ſit and look at him for ever. If he was aſleep, I'd take ſuch care that nothing ſhould diſturb him;—but I don't look at him with any pleaſure—I don't care whether he wakes or no.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [beginning to wake.] Never fear, Doctor, ſhe'll be— [yawning]—ſhe'll be a very good girl.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: To be ſure, I muſt try to be good; but I ſhall never be happy, though!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
Mind what I ſay, my pretty Bell—The
young fellows—the young fellows are all rogues, villains, and—heydey! where's the Doctor?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: He's gone to Hampſtead.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hampſtead! Why, how long have I been aſleep? Bleſs me! [looking at his watch.] 'Tis ſix o'clock.—I muſt go—A'n't you ſorry, my pretty Bell?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Not ſorry!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why muſt I be ſorry?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Becauſe I am going to leave you. When you are my wife you muſt be ſorry always in my abſence, and glad in my preſence.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why muſt I be glad?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why!—why becauſe I am with you, to talk to you, and to warn you againſt the enſnaring devices of young men, who, like ſpiders, ſpread their cobwebs every where, to catch ſuch ſilly flies as you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear me, how can you think ſo? Spiders are frightful creatures, but young men are not frightful. When my uncle took me out in his chariot, they looked at me ſo kindly! If I had been their ſiſter, they could not have ſeemed to like me better.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, they would not then have liked you ſo well. But you are very ignorant, Bell; very ignorant, indeed! However, you have time enough to improve.—When you are Lady Penmanmaure, you'll be quite a different thing. Good by'e, pretty Bell! you ſhall ſee me again to-night.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
I don't care whether I ever ſee you again or not. It's very odd now—every time I ſee him, I like him worſe and worſe; and every time I ſee Mr. Bellair
I like him better and better. [Enter SERVANT] Thomas, if Mr. Bellair ſhould come, don't ſay my uncle is out, then perhaps he'll go away, and won't come up.

sp.speaker: THOMAS.
sp.p: He is here now, Miſs. He ſeem'd very ſorry that my maſter was abſent; but ſaid he'd wait to have ſome of your ſal volatile, when his Lordſhip was gone—and he ſent me now to aſk if you'd admit him.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes!—How glad I am my Lord is gone. Dear me, now, I am all in a flutter! What can make me tremble ſo?

div.stage: Enter BELLAIR, leaning on a Servant.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Gently! gently! Support me to the ſopha.—There! now you may go. [Exit SERVANT.] Your drops, ſweet young lady!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Here they are, Sir;—I hope they'll do you good.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Do you hope ſo! [holding both her hands.]—Do you wiſh me to recover?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: There is nothing in the world I wiſh for ſo much.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Who knows but it may be in your power?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! you can't recover. My uncle ſays—and you know he is a great Doctor—that you muſt dye.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [ſtill holding her hands.] And can you bear to ſee me dye?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No, I ſhan't ſee you die; and I hope I never ſhall hear of it. But I ſhall know it; for I ſhall then ſee you no more.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I am ſorry you are in ſuch pain—you ſee how bad you are; you'll hardly be able to come any more—But I have ſomething to comfort me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What!—what!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I have your picture—I drew it myſelf—Nobody would know it to be you but me;—but I can make out all your face.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, God of Love! thou canſt have no happineſs in ſtore for me after this!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, don't fear, Sir!—you will be very happy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes!—yes, moſt adorable! I ſhall indeed be happy, for thou haſt pronounced it. See at your feet the moſt faithful and paſſionate of lovers. You have been deceived in me; I am not dying—except I dye now, through exceſs of bliſs.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Gracious!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It will take too long to explain now, how firſt I ſaw, how firſt I loved you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What do you love me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: More than my life! and I come to ſave you from miſery. You are on the brink of marriage with a man you muſt hate.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: How can you ſave me from that?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By marrying you myſelf.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What may you marry me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, ſweet innocence!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I thought I could marry nobody but that old Lord?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No, you ſhall never marry him, unleſs you chooſe it.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Chooſe it!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is but one way to prevent it;—you muſt leave your uncle's houſe, put yourſelf under my protection, and then become the miſtreſs of my fate.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: And when muſt I do this?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To-night.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Goodneſs! and is it really in my power not to marry him, and to marry you? and will it be my duty to love you, and to ſit by you, and to watch your ſlumbers?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, my angel! whilſt it continues to be your choice, never think about the duty. Will you be ready to go with me to-night?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Go with you! Yes, indeed—But where?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am now going to prevail on a friend of mine to honour his houſe, by making it your aſylum 'till you remove to your own. I will be in the ſtreet at ten; a dark lanthorn ſhall be my ſignal—The moment you perceive it, leave the roof under which your ruin has been plann'd.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I will, indeed.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Let nothing ſtop you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: No—not if my uncle was to beg ever ſo much.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: One kiſs from each dear hand—'tis all I will aſk 'till you are my own. Adieu! Remember ten.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
Can it be all true? Mr. Bellair not dying, and loves me, and I to be his wife! It is—it is! theſe
dear marks on my hands are real— [kiſſing them.] Oh, happy, happy Arabella!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Sir, a ſhentleman is without, and has creat occaſions to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Did I not ſay—

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Cot a mercy! I tolt him you ſait ſo; and he ſait you would ſee him—He is your cotſon from Leyton.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Godſon! What, Harry Bellair? Hah! [looking through the wing.] it is him, ſure enough.—Harry! come in, Harry! [Enter BELLAIR.] Why, you rogue you, how long have you been return'd from Leyden? and how can you have the impudence to be grown thus tall and big? Hark ye! take care you forget that I was a greybeard at your chriſtening, you young dog you!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At leaſt I ſhall not be ſo malicious as to remember it on your wedding-day, which I am told is very near.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hah! have you heard that? The devil's in this town for goſſiping. Formerly a man could do a ſnug thing in London, and the buſineſs as little known as though it were tranſacted on Penmanmaure—But now one's moſt private concerns are as public as the ſecrets of a prime miniſter.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why ſhould ſo ſplendid an event as your marriage—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: None of your jeers! What, I ſuppoſe, you expect to be introduced to my bride—I ſhan't do it. I ſhan't do it, godſon—There's your anſwer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then I ſhall be kinder than you; for I'll introduce you to mine—Nay, before ſhe is my bride; I'll intruſt her to your care in all her virgin charms.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No great compliment in that, perhaps. But are you going to be married then?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I hope ſo; but, to confeſs—it is a kind of a run-away buſineſs. I am this very night to carry off the lady, and I come now to ſolicit your permiſſion to bring her here.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: With all my heart—with all my heart, Harry. But who is ſhe?—what is ſhe?—whence is ſhe?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She is a blooming girl, on the point of being decoy'd into marriage with a man old enough to be her grandfather, and dotard enough to believe that the enchanted circle of a wedding ring will conjure in her a blindneſs to his defects, and a paſſion for his wrinkles.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Hay! [dryly] Why there are ſome prudent girls, Mr. Bellair, who have no objection to a huſband a little on the down-hill of life.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, I beg your pardon! I am ſure I did not mean to infinuate that—that—What is he going to marry a prudent girl?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well but—gad, 'tis laughable too. Ha, ha! How old is the little tit?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Of that delightful age which women term childiſh, and which girls think womaniſh;—ſhe is the niece of an eminent phyſician; and the man, to whom he is going to marry her, is a ſuperannuated peer.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
[aſide.] Hell and devils! But ſtay—there
are more old fools than I.—The name, Sir;—the Doctor's name?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Feelove;—and his lovely niece is Arabella Melville.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I have a red hot iron in my liver.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why do you whiſtle, Sir?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing. 'Tis a droll ſtory you tell me—that's all. And pray how did you get acquainted with the young woman?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ſaw her with her uncle in Hyde Park—was ſtruck with the air of innocence, and enquiry that diſtinguiſhed her—followed the carriage—learnt that ſhe was juſt brought from Cornwall, to be married to a gouty Lord—introduced myſelf as a patient—robb'd the niece of her heart, and let the uncle rob me of my guineas.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well done, uncle Toby!—wiſe uncle Toby! Gad, there's ſomething very odd in all this! And you are going to carry her off to-night?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: And you wiſh to bring her here?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ardently.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall take it d—d ill, if you carry her any where elſe.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: There is not another houſe in London I would truſt her in.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Bring her! bring her away! I'll take as much care of the little rogue, as though it was my own affair.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How ſhall I thank—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, you'll know what thanks to pay me in a day or two.—Go, my dear Harry!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your cagerneſs charms me.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Go—go—go! [puſhing him out.]—Ha, ha, ha!—Oh! oh! oh! I could cry heartily on one ſide, but the other won't let me for laughing. Now, which ſhall I do? Oh, a ſly gypſey! Oh, a d—d old fool of a Doctor! That he ſhould bring her a gallant!—that ſhe ſhould conſent to run off with him!—and that he ſhould humbly ſolicit to put her under my wing!!!—Well, it ſhall all work together for good. Inſtead of the Lord, may I be Goat of Penmanmoure, if this ſhan't be a means of ſqueezing me another five thouſand out of Feelove. I have it working here—'tis working here. David! David!

div.stage: [Miſs ARCHER diſcovered with a Harp, on which ſhe ſtrikes a few notes. A rapping is heard—ſhe riſes with precipitation.]

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: MY ſweet harp, I muſt abandon thee! That rap announces my ſatyriſt. Ha, ha! Now, I really wonder, though I wiſh to ſee him, how he can look me in the face:—he muſt be moſt ridiculouſly confuſed—trying at fifty awkward apologies. Oh, it is Miſs Juvenile—impatient, I ſuppoſe, to ſee the bard.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Bleſs me, is he gone! I run away the moment we roſe from table. I would not have miſs'd him for the world.—Who would have expected him to be gone ſo ſoon? Not eight yet.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Who, indeed? But people's fears, when they dread great misfortunes, are generally unruly. Why, my dear Ma'am, you'll be happy yet—The charming man who laſh'd me has not been here.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Oh, that's lucky! I do want much to ſee what ſort of a man he is.—She ſhan't know that I could tell her.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, I can draw his picture, I am ſure, exactly. A great fat man, in a black coat, with twinkling eyes, and a prodigious length of profile—he makes amazing low bows—ſits down, with his hat reſting on his knees; and after wiping his face, ſtuffs his red and white pocket handkerchief in the crown of it.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir Marvel Muſhroom, and another Gentleman.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! my dear Sir Marvel, that was in the very firſt ſtyle. Do you know—Ladies, your moſt obedient! [paſſing them with a ſliding bow]—Do you know the very thing happened to me at Padua! Miſs Archer, I am happy to wait on you.—We were all in the Marchezza's box that night, when her huſband came from Paris—ſhe is extremely handſome; he toute au contrarie! but, notwithſtanding—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Bleſs me, can't you tell your ſtory afterwards? Let me introduce you to Miſs Archer. This, Madam, is the gentleman who had honour to day to entertain the town with—with that little—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, a mere trifle! not worth mentioning, Sir Marvel. Miſs Archer, I hear you have been a traveller; and that, when in Italy, they perſuaded you to viſit ſome of the Levant Iſlands. I wonder, when ſo far, your taſte did not carry you to Greece! You can conceive nothing ſo charming as the Grecian women!—nothing ſo intereſting as their ſtyle of living!—you would have found all Arcadia realiz'd.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Greece and Arcadia!—are theſe his apologies!—his aukward embarraſsments!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I endeavoured to perſuade a fair Greek, that the fate of my countrywomen was happier than their's.—"Oh, it is impoſſible," ſaid ſhe; "their liberty makes them capricious, and their power over the men aſſuming; they grow old in planning new conqueſts, and, alive only to the pleaſure of admiration, ſeldom taſte the exquiſite bliſs of true paſſion." I felt the force of her obſervation, and could not help confeſſing that it was poſſible for a handſome Engliſh woman to border on the ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: [Aſide] So! that's tolerably home.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aſide] I am petrified! he talks with as much ſelf-poſſeſſion as he would to a maiden aunt—no bearing this!

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: So you will not know me, Mr. Carlton?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Miſs Juvenile!—'tis no wonder I did not immediately recollect you in that dreſs, when I left you in a white frock. I ſaw your brother well at Vienna. You play, Miſs Archer. I am charm'd that you prefer the harp—'tis ſo graceful for the lady—ſo advantageous for the voice.

sp.speaker: MARV.
