sp.p: [In a pet] Why 'tis downright jingle!—a wooden cimbal is a better thing! I thought to have heard nothing but what concern'd my ver—I mean your verſes; and here you have whiſk'd us to Padua, then to Greece, then we had a ſwing to Vienna in Turkey, and now we muſt have a Canterbury tale about the merits of the Welch harp. Why, I tell you, Miſs Archer, this is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p:
Yes, Miſs Archer, this is the gentleman,
who travell'd all over Europe, to qualify himſelf to write an epigram on you;—I think he might have managed the matter without going ſo far for his wit.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: If he got his wit far off, you muſt allow it touches home.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Yes;—I allow it is homely wit.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Heavens! how could this man! [aſide] Miſs Juvenile means to be ſevere upon you, Sir, but don't be diſheartened. When you have done with me, you'll find a number of innocent, unprotected characters, who, at no other expence than a private heart-ache, may be ſecurely offered up victims to your muſe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I diſclaim all connection with the muſes—nothing inſpires me but the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: You were happy in the choice of a ſubject to day; was he not, my dear? Have you the paper about you, Sir Marvel?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, to be ſure—here it is.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pardon me! I am not yet ſo harden'd a writer, as to ſtand the reading of my own works.
sp.stage: [Snatches the paper with anger, and puts it in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aſide] Now, would I give the world to know, if that is in compaſſion to his own feelings, or to mine.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir! not hear your own works! Why, it is what every body does, and read 'em too.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, to be ſure—the ladies carry their's about in their netting caſes, and the men in their toothpick caſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed;—we learn thoſe kind of
works now, like every other, at boarding ſchool. I, myſelf, have written five odes, ſeven epigrams, and an elegy on an old turkey cock. Come, read, Mr. Carlton—you'll give your ſatire new points.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Theſe wretches will force me to ſpoil my plan, by their cruelty to the lovely ſufferer.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: May I be permitted to aſk, how I came to have the honour of your poetical notice?—Did I ever offend you?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Never, Madam! with reſpect to me, you have been perfectly harmleſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Would I had not! for the firſt time in my life I wiſh to do miſchief.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I never had the honour of your acquaintance; and have ſeen you but ſeldom in public; but laſt ſpring I particularly remember, at the Pantheon.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: That's well! particularly remember!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It was impoſſible to forget it;—you had in your party ſo lovely a girl! Bright blue eyes, flaxen treſſes, elegant ſhape, modeſt—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [Impatiently] What has all this to do with your ſatire on me, Sir? Why have you taken pains to repreſent me to the world in ſo odious a light?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, one does many things without reflection. I happened to be in the humour to write—Your name occurred—The thing was done—My friends liked it—They would have it appear. I'll give you leave to abuſe me with fifty times the wit.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Fifty times as much wit! gad! I don't know where ſhe'd find it.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Then you do not think me, Sir, ſo very—I underſtand, you do not think me ſo extremely odious and frightful!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, that ſubmiſſive look! ſuch another will bring me at her feet, and then I am undone.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Do you hear, Mr. Carlton? is the lady ſo very odious, and frightful?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Frightful! Oh, no, Madam. The lady is very well—I wiſh I had abated a point or two in my epigram. She is tolerably fair, not a very bad ſhape, and, upon the whole, a—a moſt bewitching creature.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, do you think I can ſtand here to be analyzed in this manner? Pardon me, if I ſay you ſcarcely keep within the line of good manners. I did not expect—not that I care.—I would not have you think that—that—I can bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, thoſe tears! that I could catch them, and bury them in my heart!

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—well, ſhe's finely mortified. My dear Mr. Carlton, I have the moſt extreme favour to beg of you.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: You have intereſt with the news-papers—I have ſome very elegant, ſpirited things, and ſhall be prodigouſly obliged, if you'll get 'em in for me.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Ma'am, I really—

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Nay, I will not be denied.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: No, no,—don't deny the lady.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: A word! [Takes him aſide.] I have one thing that would cut Sir Marvel to ſhivers.—If you will but get that one thing publiſhed.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes, get that one thing publiſhed, by all means.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: To oblige you, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Oh, charming!—I'll bring it to you myſelf to-morrow. Now I'll go to Miſs Archer, and tell her you are going home to compoſe another ſatire on her.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Go, thou thing! and proſecute my heart's deareſt intereſts, whilſt you believe yourſelf only gratifying your girliſh ſpite!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: In the midſt of all Miſs Archer's anger, ſhe does not pretend to deſpiſe the verſes.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Deſpiſe them! I deſign to make her acknowledge that they are the happieſt verſes that ever were written;—you have really very extraordinary talents.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Talents!—aye, but every body thinks he has talents now-a-days! as Homer ſays in the Rape of the Lock,
sp.l: To wit each blockhead makes pretence;
Give me a little common ſenſe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Amen, Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Mighty pretty! mighty pretty! I can never come in to my houſe, but I am joſtled by two or three young fellows going out of it. Hark ye, Sir! In future when any body, male or female, aſks for Miſs Archer, ſay ſhe's not at home. If I can't get her out of the houſe, ſhe ſhall ſee nobody in it—that will ſurely do in the long run. She may live without a huſband, but to live without goſſiping, without flatterers, without all the he and ſhe family of nonſenſe, that I take to be impoſſible. D'ye mind me?

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes ſure I to, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Well then, mind me again. Mr. Bellair will bring a lady here preſently—tell him I am out—ſent for by the Welch Committee, about the new linen manufactory;—but ſay I left ſtrict orders with the houſekeeper to take care of the lady.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, aye—they are together by this time, driving to me, their only friend and guardian! ha, ha, ha! I ſaw the dog watching the door, and I ſaw him hold up a lantern—that was the ſignal, I ſuppoſe, ha, ha, ha!—Pretty creatures! Oh, I have them faſt—they have made a nooſe for their own necks. Of an unfortunate man, I am ſurely the moſt fortunate that ever.

sp.speaker: BELLAIR,
sp.p: At the committee, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My deareſt angel 'tis unfortunate; but you are now in the houſe of Mr. Evergreen, and his protection will be of the moſt concluſive ſort, with reſpect to your reputation; and your reputation is now mine. Why do you ſigh?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: I don't know—but I am afraid they'll take me from you again.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Never; I ſwear by every thing ſacred, that I'll hold you to me as I would my life. I'll go directly down to the houſe to bring home my friend; I cannot bear that you ſhould be in this unguarded ſlate, and for many reaſons I ought not to remain with you.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Not remain with me! why are we not to be married?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p:
Doubtleſs! and then we ſhall be inſeperable;
but cuſtom ſays we muſt not be ſo 'till we are married.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why, how will cuſtom know any thing about us?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, there are a thouſand eyes upon us. Of what a nature is innocence! it invites its ruin; and the more pure it is, the nearer to deſtruction. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Well, if you muſt leave me, make haſte to return. How ſhall I amuſe myſelf in your abſence? Oh, here are ſome paintings. I love paintings dearly—I can look at them and make out whole converſations, between unhappy girls, and their croſs uncles, and fathers.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But look now, my angel, for another ſubject—ſearch for the portrait of a lover; fancy him telling the beauty he adores, that his whole life is devoted to her felicity;—fancy that I am that lover, and yourſelf the charming girl. [kiſſing her hand] Heaven guard thee!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: The happy girl, he ſhould have ſaid. Oh, I ſhall find no portrait here ſo charming as he is.

div.stage: [As ſhe is looking at the paintings, EVERGREEN enters, and ſtands in her way;—ſhe turns, and ſeeing him, ſhrieks.]

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How now, young woman! why ſo frightened?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! oh dear!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How came you here, child—hey?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: How—Oh goodneſs! how came you here?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, I am intimate here—I make as free as though I were at home.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Indeed!—Oh, he'll go and tell my uncle where to find me. What ſhall I do? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, Bell! Bell! have I not always told you to beware of young men? have I not told you that they are all made up of deceit and lies?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, you have told me ſo, but I don't believe you. And you told me that I was made on purpoſe to be your wife, and that I don't believe neither.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Indeed! why, who then are you made for?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Somebody.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, but not for the body you think of, my pretty Bell. Oh, you little gooſe you! why this was a ſcheme plan'd between Bellair and me. This is my houſe; and he has brought you here, to deliver you ſolely into my power.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, what a ſtory! how can you ſay ſuch falſe things? he'd die before he'd put me in your power.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Would he ſo? why I have been in his ſecret the whole time. I know of his ſham ſickneſs to impoſe on your wiſe uncle, and of his perſuading you that he had a godfather, under whoſe care he would place you. I know of the ſignal of the dark lantern, and every particular about ye—Now what do you think of young men?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Think! oh merciful! I could not have believ'd that in all the world there had been ſuch—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, now, are they not deceitful monſters? and Bellair in particular, is he not—tell me? [ſnatching her hand] is he not the worſt of men?—a moſt cruel villain?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What for putting me in your power?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: No, no, no,—I mean for—'Gad ſhe had me!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, it is very cruel indeed. I think now I could hate him. Oh, I wiſh he would come, that I might tell him how I hate him!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, but he won't come—or, if he does, it will be to no purpoſe; he ſhall never ſee you more, my pretty Bell, 'till you are my wife.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: If I was ſure it would make him miſerable, I could almoſt determine to be your wife—and yet I would rather die.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, you ungrateful baggage! ſo much love, ſo much tenderneſs as I have thrown away upon you!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Its very ſtrange! I would help it if I could, but indeed I cannot. He who has been ſo cruel, I cannot hate; and you, who have been ſo kind, I cannot love.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I am much obliged t'ye, Ma'am, for your confidence.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Why ſhould I deceive you?—you think Mr. Bellair very wicked in deceiving me, and pretending to love me, when he did not. I will not pretend to love you; if I did, you ought to think me a very wicked girl.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo. Well, Ma'am, with regard to the matter of love, we'll ſettle that hereafter;—perhaps we are more even there than you think for—but, at preſent, I have other buſineſs in hand. Here, Mrs. Jones, [Enter Houſekeeper] take care of this young lady;—tempt her to eat if you can, and if you cannot, put her to bed ſupperleſs.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Muſt I go to bed without ſeeing Mr. Bellair, to reproach him.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I'll reproach, when the time comes, never fear; but he ſhan't enter theſe doors to night. Go, Mrs. Jones—go! [Exeunt.] Now will I to my Doctor; by this time he is apprized of his loſs; and I'll ſee him poiſon'd before I'll tell him where ſhe is. Oh, Doctor! Doctor!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Go down, Mrs. Jones, I'll comfort the young lady. My ſweet girl, who are ye? what is the occaſion of this extreme diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, you ſeem good-natured, and I'll tell ye. Mr. Bellair has betrayed me, and Lord Penmanmawr is determined to marry me.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Who are theſe people?—I never heard their names.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Dear!—why this muſt be a very large houſe then, for Lord Penmanmawr lives in it; and Mr. Bellair I run away with, to marry—but I don't know where he lives.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Heavens! run away with a man to marry him, and not know where he lives! why, my dear, he may be a deceiver.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Yes, ſo he is, a very great deceiver; for he brought me here to Lord Panmanmawr, and call'd him Mr. Evergreen;—and now he won't marry me himſelf, and wants to force me to marry the old lord. [Weeping.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
Lord Penmanmawr, and call'd him Evergreen! I don't know what to underſtand. But come, my love, you ſhall go with me to my dreſſing
room, and we'll talk it over;—if you want an adviſer, you ſhall find a ſincere one in me. Her heart has an attachment, and it ſeems an unfortunate one—I know too well, now, how to pity her.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE,
sp.p: Gone! gone! gone off! I can't believe it—'tis impoſſible. She knows nobody—ſpeaks to nobody. In all this vaſt town there cannot be a houſe open to her. And here have I been ſent on a fool's errand to Hampſtead, where every body is in health—not a ſoul ſick from the top of the Heath, to Mother Red Caps. But ſhe can't be gone off!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye, here's a fine pill for ye, Doctor!—here's a bitter potion! Whilſt you have been running after an old woman's ſciatica at Hampſtead, your niece has been running away with a young man.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What are we to do? Why do we ſtand here? Why don't we go in ſearch of her?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Search of her!—where? where are we to go? And if we find her, what then? who d'ye think is to take your tarniſh'd plate off your hands? We, indeed! 'tis all your affair, now Doctor; I waſh my hands on't entirely.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: What do you mean? Why, is ſhe not contracted to you?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Contracted to me—yes, in a ſtate of unblemiſhed reputation.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Her reputation is yet unblemiſhed, Sir.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, but it won't be ſo to-morrow morning—the firſt ſun beams will ſee the flies upon it, and by noon it will be ſtale—ſtale, Doctor!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir! this is going too far;—you are too violent in your conjectures;—after all it may be but a girl's frolic—ſtray'd to ſome toyſhop, or confectioner's, perhaps.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Toyſhop! or confectioner's! [contemptuouſly] What, then, you have not found out, all this time, that ſhe is really run off with a young fellow, and who her gallant is! whu! have I that news to tell you? come, Doctor, prepare for a ſurprize—looſen your neckcloth, take off your wig, ſlacken all your ligatures, and ſit down for a fit.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: [Angrily] Slacken your wit, Sir! you are too jocoſe on the ſubject of a young lady's reputation.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Young lady's repution! there are more reputations than her's at ſtake, I promiſe ye;—the reputation of a wiſe man—a Doctor's reputation, will become the tennis ball of all the wits in town in a few hours. Oh, Doctor, Doctor! where did you take up your diploma for diſcretion?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir! there is no bearing—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
Yes, but there is—Hark ye! I ſhall make ye, in one minute, as mute as the buſt of old Galen in your ſtudy. This great, impudent, roaring, debauch'd fellow, who has carried off your niece without let or hindrance, is the poor puling patient, who was brought to your houſe every day for the benefit of the park air; and whom you have pronounced to be beyond
the ſkill of all the phyſicians in Europe, to keep out of a winding ſheet.—Now, Doctor, you find there are more reputations than your niece's at ſtake.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: A malicious invention of your own—ſheer malice!—That poor young gentleman is in a ſtate, and I will prove it, to make it impoſſible for him to recover. The morbid matter (ſpeaking very eagerly) hourly increaſes; the viſcera do not perform their functions—ſecretion is deſtroyed—the thorax inflamed, the—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: I tell you he is run away with your niece.

sp.speaker: (FEELOVE
sp.stage: continues to ſpeak without regarding the other's interruptions.)
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, that ſuch an attack on my character
(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—a man of my experience, Mr. Evergreen
—(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—I who am acknowledged by every apothecary within the bills of mortality
—(I tell you is run away with your niece)
—[Going off, the other following]—I who am call'd to every capital conſultation
—(I tell you he is run away with your niece)
—I whoſe practice has been ſo ſingularly ſucceſsful—

sp.speaker: BELLAIR.
sp.p: My dear Carlton, congratulate me!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Congratulate me!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have carried off my prize.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have been with Miſs Archer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have ſafely lodged her in the houſe of a friend.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have ſeen the moſt tender melancholy in her air.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have ſeen love light up all her features; and have preſſed my Arabella to my heart.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I have preſs'd Miſs Archer to mine too, in idea; and my hopes tell me, that it will not be only in idea. I am now convinced of her ſenſibility, and adore her. But where is your Arabella?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: At the friends I mentioned. Not being able to find him at Weſtminſter, I called at his houſe in my return, and have been aſſured that the dear girl herſelf, Mr. Evergreen, and all the family are retired to reſt.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Evergreen! he's Miſs Archer's guardian—ſhe lives in his houſe.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Then our Miſtreſſes are under the ſame roof—that's moſt fortunate!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It is indeed; for two girls talking to each other of the men they love, will do more for us in a day, than we could for ourſelves in a week.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove! Oh, all the demons of miſchance!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Can he have made the diſcovery ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
[Speaking as he enters.] A villain! to attempt thus to undermine my reputation. Gentlemen,—I have been inſulted ſo groſsly, that I can hardly compoſe myſelf, to tell you the cauſe of my unſeaſonable
viſit—but—if—in one word, how is my poor patient—how is Mr. Bellair?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir! Mr. Bellair—Sir!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: He does not know ye—fear nothing.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: My patient, Sir—good gentlemen ſpeak! how is my patient?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your patient, Sir, is as well as a patient can be, who is out of the reach of his d—d Doctor. No further occaſion for aſſes milk, ſtimulatives, balſamics, or coolers.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Alas, poor Doctor!—no more fees—he has given you the go-by fairly. Is it not a ſhame that a man of your proweſs in the fields of Galen, ſhould not be able to conquer ſuch a pitiful hectic as drove him him out of the world? why, a phyſician ought to have the diſeaſes at his call, and whiſtle them on and off, as a huntſman does his hounds.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Aye, 'twas a crying ſin, to let ſuch a ſpirited fine young fellow be kick'd out of life by a raſcally little feveret! An old woman would have cured him; but ſuch an obſtinate confidence in the ſkill of the renown'd Doctor Feelove! He died full of reſentment, and his laſt words were—"Toſs the Doctor in a blanket."

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I can forgive that—I can forgive that—but I can't forgive your illiberality, Sir. An old woman cure him! It was not in the power of all the phyſicians between London and the Alps to cure him;—not an herb, gum, wood, or fungus in the whole medicopeia, that could have given him breath two days longer.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe, Sir—Bring the blanket!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I could not bear this treatment, Sir, but that the extreme ſatisfaction I have in Mr. Bellair's death.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Satisfaction!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. My reputation, my character, demanded that he ſhould die.—I would not have had him alive to-morrow morning for a thouſand pound fee.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This is amazing!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Why, Sir, there is a vile ſtory in circulation, which, if true, would ſink me beneath the loweſt med'cine grinder—beneath a mixer of eggs and turpentine—beneath the cork in a julep bottle; nothing leſs than that Bellair is in perfect health, and ſo alive to youth and beauty, as to have run away with my niece—they ſay that!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: What is there this world will not ſay! By all the honour of phyſic, he has a doſe in his pocket to have ſecured his reputation, had he found thee alive!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: [Apart] We'll ſearch him, and make him ſwallow it. But have you then loſt the young lady?—is ſhe gone?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Gone, Sir—abſolutely gone; but as my poor patient is gone too, I am in ſome meaſure reconciled to that event. But, bleſs me, Sir, you are vaſtly like him—a man more liable to be impoſed on, might take ye both for the ſame perſon;—the ſame voice, and the ſame features, only freſher and plumper.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Oh, oh—What you have found me out, Doctor? Why, I am his brother—your poor patient's younger brother,—and I ſhould break my heart for his death, only the dog has left me a clear eſtate of two
thouſand a year, to buy weepers. In ſhort, Doctor, I greatly fear'd your ſkill would preſerve him, and if it had!—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Preſerve him! you might as well have expected my ſkill in phyſic to have preſerv'd the French bank from breaking.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, notwithſtanding my affected petulance at your entrance, I am highly gratified that Bellair is where he is—and I'll recommend you to all my friends and acquaintance. But I wonder the loſs of your niece ſits ſo lightly, my little Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I have a great heart—a prodigious great heart! its feelings are for the faculty. A girl may run away from an uncle without reproach to him; but when a patient runs away from the ſentence of his phyſician, the reputation of the doctor muſt ſoon run after him.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Happily our patient knew his duty better;—and ſo, as we are now three very happy fellows, let us e'en adjourn to the Star and Garter, and live the evening like bon vivants.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: With all my heart;—and egad, gentlemen, I am ſo offended with the inſolence of a certain perſon, whom I will not name, that if you'll diſcover my niece, I'll give her to ye, with a fortune of twenty thouſand pounds. The odd ten I'll ſtick to.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Hah! ſay ye ſo? If I diſcover her, ſhall ſhe be my reward?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That ſhe ſhall.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: May I rely on your promiſe.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p:
With as much confidence, as on the
ſymptoma of a fever. I would give her to a rincer of gallipots, rather than the perſon I had engaged her to;—to a pill vender—to a mountebank.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bravo, Doctor! keep to that, and we'll diſcover her enchanted caſtle, never fear!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: That we will. Allons! let us ſacrifice to Bacchus to-night, and to-morrow to Eſculapius, and Fortune!

div.stage: Enter FEELOVE, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: NOTHING of my niece this morning! Oh, may that raſcal, who cheated me yeſterday to Hampſtead, never get rid of his wife till he is ſeventy-ſix; and then, for his farther puniſhment, may he grow rich, and fall in love!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: May I be ſo bold, Sir—is that a curſe?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: A curſe! why, can there be greater, than for a man to fall into riches, when he has neither time nor faculties to enjoy them; and to fall in love, whilſt he is falling into his grave? If they are bleſſings, may they be the lot of knaves, and cowards, and quacks! Bring me the ſlate, that I may ſee where I am to go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Go! why go to find your niece, to be ſure. Have you heard nothing from her yet?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Come, how much will you add now to the fifteen thouſand, if I ſhould diſcover, and bring her t'ye?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What! conſider what you ſay!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: I do conſider what I ſay!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How! if I diſcover your niece, drag her from her ſeducer, and in that ſtate of her reputation take her off your hands, and make her Miſtreſs Evergreen—what will you not throw in five thouſand for that?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: No, Miſter Evergreen—not five guineas—not five ſhillings—not a ſingle half-crown. Oh, how I could mortify him now, by telling him Bellair is dead!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Here! here's an unreaſonable man! So then, if I diſcover, and marry her, I am to have only fifteen thouſand pounds!—Oh Lord! oh Lord!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Fifteen thouſand pounds! why you ſhan't have her at all. Fifteen thouſand pounds! If I thought my niece would ever look upon thee, or ever think of thee as a huſband, I'd put fifteen thouſand pounds in each pocket, drive to Graveſend, and leap into the ſea, to diſappoint thee.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Why, we'd have you up again, if you did—we'd empty your pockets, I warrant you. Riches are no more ſafe now in the bottom of the ſea, than a rainbow is in the clouds. Neither earth, ſea, or air, in this happy age, can keep their ſecrets from us; and I have no doubt but ſome bold adventurer in the next, will find out a way to live in fire; or dart from continent to continent, like Milton's angels, on a condens'd ſun-beam.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: That may be poſſible; but for you to marry my niece, with my conſent, is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: What, are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: In earneſt—aye, as earneſt as you was in your abuſe of me laſt night. Smoke the Doctor, I ſuppoſe, was the word. You love a joke, old friend; ſo do I; and mine ſhall coſt leſs than your's—ſo good morning t'ye! I ſhall preſcribe another huſband for my niece, depend on't.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Say you ſo, my old boy? Why then I muſt play a game I did not think of—I muſt ſecure the young woman 'till you can be brought to alter your preſcription. I have made a pretty meſs here! 'Gad, though I love a joke, I did not think I was buying mine at the dear rate of fifteen thouſand pounds—Dangerous joking with doctors I find. Well, well, a wiſe man may fall into miſtakes as well as a fool; but a wiſe man will find a way to remedy them.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I am charm'd to ſee you ſo well this morning. Has Lord Penmanmawr viſited you?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, yes; and he left me to go to my uncle's; but I made him promiſe not to tell that I am here.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: You did not hint that you knew him to be Mr. Evergreen?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, no—I will do nothing but what you bid me. I ſhould be eaſy now, could I but ſee Mr. Bellair, to vent my anger, and to tell him how I hate him.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
Have a care, my dear girl! you
wiſh to ſee him, I have no doubt; but ſhould he appear, you'd forget your motives for that wiſh.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, never! was there ever ſo baſe—ſo—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Never, I acknowledge it; yet, ſhould he invent any plauſible excuſe, your greedy ear would ſwallow it all. May I not judge her from myſelf? Should Mr. Carlton form excuſes, where would my reſentments be?

div.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, ſpeaking at the Wing.

sp.speaker: EVERGREEN.
sp.p: So! there's Satan at the ear of Eve [Aſide]. Did I not deſire, Miſs Archer, that you would hold no correſpondence with this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Yes, my dear Guardian, and therefore I made a point of ſeeing her, and giving her a little ſiſterly advice. She knows by this time how to deceive your vigilance on common occaſions, and on uncommon ones I have promiſed to aſſiſt her.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aſſiſt her! (contemptuouſly) Well, Miſs Melville, are you prepar'd to meet your uncle?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! is he coming!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: How he gain'd knowledge of your being here, I know not, unleſs it is from your falſe Bellair; but he ſwears vengeance—a garret and water-gruel are the leaſt of his threats.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, Miſs Archer! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
What ſignifies appealing to her? Miſs Archer, indeed! I have contrived what is to become of you; for I would not deliver my little Bell up to her uncle in his preſent fury for a dukedom, and to conceal you from him here will be impoſſible; I have therefore
a chaiſe ready at the door, to carry you a few miles out of town.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Out of town!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Yes, Madam—or in town, or where I pleaſe—you won't preſume to interfere, I hope.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I hope Miſs Melville will refuſe to go.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Let her at her peril! ſhe is my affianc'd wife; my wife betroth'd—I have perfect right over her. Go you, Madam, to your apartment, and leave her to my care.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My dear Girl, never go with him; who knows where he may carry you!

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: What can I do? I fear to go with him, and I am terrified to death at the thoughts of ſeeing my uncle.

div.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, with a long white ſtuff Cloak, and large Hood.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Here, here's a Welch riding-cloak, that belonged to a tall, meagre aunt of mine; 'tis a little too long, I believe; but it will conceal you the better. Put it on, and pull the hood over, that your face mayn't be ſeen. Nay, don't be reſtive, Miſs (throwing it looſely over her): put it on, whilſt I repleniſh my purſe.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Lady, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My ſweet Girl, how can I aſſiſt you? What an arbitrary wretch! I am full of grief for you—What has not this Bellair to anſwer for?

div.stage: [They weep over each other, retiring back.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
I muſt give up Hyde Park this morning—I'd be ſworn Carlton will be here, and I am determined
to make one in their tête-à-tête. Hey, hey! why, Ladies!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [turning] Oh, Sir Marvel!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: And weeping too! Dionyſius-like—no, Niobe-like, all tears.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: A thought ſtrikes me—you can aſſiſt us. My guardian is going to hurry this young lady out of town, we know not where.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Aye, I ſaw the chaiſe at the door—ſhall I go and break the axle, or ſhoot the horſes?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: No, no—put on this cloak [taking it from the ground]—ride with him a few miles, then turn upon him, and terrify him to death. I ſuppoſe your vis-a-vis is waiting; I'll uſe it, to convey her out of his reach—inſtantly—inſtantly!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Stop! [when the cloak is half on] Hold! I will not be envelop'd in this new-faſhion'd chemiſe—how could I be ſuch a good-natur'd fool? Have you not repuls'd me, Madam—diſdain'd me?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Sir Marvel! conſider, 'tis for this young lady—ſhe has not repuls'd you.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I'm at one word—off it goes, unleſs you'll promiſe to receive me on terms.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh heavens! I—I—I'll do better; I'll introduce you on terms to the pretty widow, Lady Beauville—ſhe's juſt becoming the rage—'twill be infinite eclat—ſhe had all the men in the pit about her t'other night at the opera.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: On with it! we are upon honour—you ſhall carry me there to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: To-night—any time. Come, Miſs Melville!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: So, here am I going, Jupiter knows where, caſed up like the Trojans in a wooden horſe, or like—but here comes my raviſher.

div.stage: Enter EVERGREEN, tying up his purſe.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, what Madam has left you! Aye, ſhe's a bad girl, Bell—a bad girl! never heed her! Come, don't cry, that's a good girl!—Devil take the ſtring! Hide your face though as much as you will—that's right, pull the hood cloſer, for who knows but the Doctor may come athwart us, to ſome Hampſtead patient or other? Come, now I am ready. Come, I ſay! [Takes Sir Marvel's hand, who goes a ſtep or two, and then ſtops.] Why d'ye ſtop, child—go you muſt and ſhall, ſo loitering will have no effect, but to make me angry. Come, I ſay—nay, if you will be pull'd, you ſhall be pull'd [Pulls and puſhes him]. Zounds! you are ſtrong, Bell; I have heard that the Corniſh girls can wreſtle, and I fancy you have practis'd the ſport. Nay, if you are for that, Miſs—here, David, come and help pull this young lady into the chaiſe.

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: [Pulling] Cot a mercy, Sir! I can't make hur ſtir a petty-toe.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Give her a pinch on the arm.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Zounds! let me alone—I will not go, by Jupiter!

sp.speaker: DAVID.
sp.p: [Flying off] What is it, Sir—it muſt be the tevil in a planket.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p:
[ſurpris'd.] What is it? why, a great country hoyden—they'll ſwear and romp at home, like
fifty grenadiers, and when they come to town, they mince their words, and mince their ſteps, as though they could utter nothing but monoſyllables, or ſtep above two inches. Come, we'll have t'other tug, Miſs—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Will you? [Raiſes the hood, and looks, firſt at one, then at the other]. Now, Mr. Evergreen, we'll have a tug, or a wreſtle, or what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Oh, that devil Miſs Archer! this muſt be her contrivance—Where are they, where are they?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Where? why, they are in the mode, that's all—emigrating. No, you don't paſs this ſtreight—you don't indeed; I'll defend it as the Africans did Thermopylae.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: You, Sir! how dare you take this liberty in my houſe?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Come, Sir, don't be obſtreperous: if you are, I'll clothe you in the riding-hood, and cram you into the poſt-chaiſe, as you would have done me; you won't play the Corniſh romp as manfully as I did.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Sir, this inſolence—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Nay, if you will have a tug, you ſhall have a tug— [Scuffle to get on the cloak, Evergreen gets off at laſt]. Here, then, I remain conqueror; but whether the game is Olympic, Iſthmian, or Iriſh, I know not. But Lady Beauville!—to be enroll'd in her ſuit, and in the Mennil hunt, is all that remains to eſtabliſh me—fate can do no more! Miſs Archer will now be a friend indeed! Oh, Pylades, as Juvenal ſays, what's life without a friend?—its a dumpling without egg.

div.stage: Enter MISS ARCHER and ARABELLA, followed by a Maid.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Tell Mrs. Tomſon, pray, that I am here. Come, cheer up my love; now we are ſafe;—that dear Sir Marvel has obliged me for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: My dear young lady!—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: My good Mrs. Tomſon, this lady wiſhes to have an apartment here for a few days—Can you accommodate her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I congratulate you, Miſs Melville; you will be here perfectly at eaſe.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Not unleſs you give ſome charge about Mr. Evergreen. The dread of ſeeing him will keep me in perpetual diſquiet.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: You know my Guardian—On no pretence admit him, whilſt Miſs Melville is in your houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: I ſhall take care, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Then adieu! I muſt hurry back inſtantly, leſt he ſhould ſend to watch the carriage;—but you ſhall ſee me again in half an hour.

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh dear! I am ſo ſorry that you muſt leave me! I love you already better than any body, except—I mean, I love you better than every body.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I comprehend ye, my Love—adieu!

div.stage: [Goes with her to the wing. CARLTON enters.]

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Angels! and miniſters of grace! Miſs Archer!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Mr. Carlton!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Come to ſeek me in my lodgings! By Heaven, this is too much! Oh, oh, now then one knows how to catch a coquette. How charm'd I am to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: How could you think of following me here, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aſide.] That's well put. Follow you here! I'd follow ye all over the globe. Now don't put on that cold look—It neither becomes the face nor the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [Aſide.] His familiarity mortifies me even more than his ſatire. How can you have the preſumption, Sir—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Madam, on ſome occaſions not to have preſumption would be ungrateful.—I ſhould really be aſhamed if at this moment I did not give you reaſon to believe that I have as much preſumption as any unmarried gentleman in town.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Intolerable! Why do you take ſuch liberties with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Why do you take ſuch liberties with me? You have taken the liberty to intrude yourſelf into my thoughts without my deſiring it; you have taken the liberty to obtrude yourſelf on my dreams—ſleeping or waking, I am never free from you. If I mean to be civil to another woman, your image pops itſelf before me, and ſteals the compliment for which ſhe was preparing her ſmiles—Talk of liberties, indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
How dares he treat me thus? The
object of his ſatire in public, and of his jeſts in private!—I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Bend your eyes on me, ſweet creature, that I may interpret them.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: If by bending them on you, I could convey to you the ſentiments with which you have inſpired me, you ſhould have their moſt pointed glances.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: [Aſide.] "The ſentiments I have inſpired!" Now, that, ſpoken in this apartment, muſt be taken as the beginning of a declaration—and it would be ſcandalous to be behind-hand. I aſſure you, Madam, I am extremely grateful to thoſe ſentiments, and beg to aſſure you, that mine for you are exactly what the moſt charming woman in the world ought to ſuppoſe them.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I don't know what I ought to ſuppoſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You ought to ſuppoſe that you are lovely, and that I have eyes:—you ought to ſuppoſe that you have a charming ſpirit, and that I have a heart:—you ought to ſuppoſe that you are captivating, and that I am your ſlave. Now how the devil have I been drawn in to make this ruinous confeſſion?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: There is an air of ſincerity about you at this moment, that almoſt convinces me you do not deceive me; and I rejoice in it. I would have you love me, I would have you adore me—that your puniſhment may be ſevere; for if I could think on you with any ſentiments but thoſe of contempt, I ſhould deſpiſe myſelf.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
I congratulate ye, Mr. Carlton—I congratulate ye! Fallen into the very ſnare that, with all thy
boaſted knowledge of the ſex, thou haſt laboured to avoid—truſted a coquette with thy paſſion, without firſt being aſſured that thou hadſt touch'd her heart. But who could have doubted, after a viſit at my lodgings?—Pſhaw! [ſtriking his forehead] 'twas clearly to draw me in;—ſhe penetrated my deſign, and determined to ſhew me a poor, ridiculous, miſerable plotter. Well, I love her the better for that! Now will it be impoſſible for that Hyaena to do any one thing, for me or againſt me, but I ſhall love her the better for it. And how ſhall I be uſed?—worſe than a dog! But I'll have thee—Yes, by Heaven! thou dear, proud, bewitching ſlut, I'll have thee, ſpite of every artifice that coquetry and female ſweetneſs can deviſe▪—'Faith, I'll go and tell her ſo now, in the very teeth of her malice.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Don't make me mad—don't make me mad! I tell you I know no more where the girl is than you do.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Not know where ſhe is? Heaven! what can this mean? Did not I leave her under your protecting roof? Did not you aſſure me—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: [Interrupting] Aſſure ye! what the devil ſignifies aſſurances, when the will of a woman is concerned? How could I gueſs that ſhe'd run away from my protecting roof?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This cannot ſatisfy me, Sir; you have an air of being angry at my enquiries, rather than ſorry for the occaſion of them.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Angry! ſo I am; d—d angry. Why, ſhe has run from me not from you. Who cares about your concern?—What buſineſs have you with her?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye; now here he is ſtaring—now we muſt have explanations. Why, then, in three words, your Bell is my Bell;—you carried her off to prevent her marriage with Lord Penmanmawr, and brought her to the houſe of Mr. Evergreen, who is Lord Penmanmawr.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye—what you can't comprehend yet?—all ſtare and wonder!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You that old Lord to whom my Arabella was to have been ſacrificed!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Aye—and you, to expedite the ſacrifice, brought her to the altar.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? What, throw my dove into the talons of the hawk!—bring the lovely creature to the very houſe ſhe meant to fly from!—Oh, fool, fool! [Traverſing the ſtage impatiently.] Now then, old gentleman, I am to conſider you as my rival—every other tie is diſſolved; and as my rival, I inſiſt on your revealing where you have hid the lady?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Don't challenge me—don't think of challenging me, you blood-thirſty wretch—I will not be challenged. 'Tis time ſome ſcheme were hit upon to ſave men of fortune from you duelling blades—We ought to be allowed to fight by proxy, as the militia do—I'd ſubſcribe an hundred guineas towards the corps, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I don't wiſh to challenge you, Sir; I am no
dueliſt, but I muſt know where my Arabella is—I will kneel at your feet if——

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Tell you where ſhe is? I ſwear by the honour of an ancient Briton I do not know; and if I did know, I would not inform you—Tell you where my Arabella is!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am frozen—Why did ſhe fly? Did ſhe not know that—But why do I ſtay queſtioning, when I ought to ſeek her?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Nay, if you are for that, I'll ſeek her too—perhaps luck may for once favour ſixty, inſtead of ſix and twenty; and if I catch her, youngſter, I ſhall mind your ohs and ahs no more than the winds upon Snowdon—He won't challenge me, I believe.

div.stage: BELLAIR re-enters, ſtealing in, as though fearful of being ſeen by EVERGREEN.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I cannot believe but that ſhe is yet in this houſe—She could not ſurely fly from it; for, with her extreme inexperience, this town muſt appear a great gulph to her, in which her innocence would every moment be in danger of being loſt. [Looking about.] Carlton's Miſs Archer lives here—if I could find her ſhe might give me ſome inſight. None of the ſervants about? [Looking through the wing.]—No one of whom I can enquire?—Shall I venture to look into the apartments?

div.stage: Enter FEELOVE, ſpeaking, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Juſt gone out! Well, when he returns give him theſe parchments—they may do for his taylor—it is the only way to make them uſeful now.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Doctor Feelove!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Hah! Mr. Bellair—where have you been all the morning? Have you found my niece? The vile ſtory I told you of, has got air—Have you heard of my niece, I ſay?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Heard of her! why, Sir, ſhe was in this houſe—ſhe ſlept here laſt night.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: In this houſe!—ſlept in the houſe of Mr. Evergreen!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Aſſuredly; and has been ſpirited away this morning.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: You ſhould as ſoon make me believe ſhe ſlept in the palace of the Grand Turk.—She in this houſe!—You may as well ſay ſhe is gone to breakfaſt in the moon, and turn'd lunatic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What obſtinacy! Why, Sir, I tell you that I myſelf—I ſay, Sir, that I—I have enquir'd, and I have been aſſured—

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Aye, poor young gentleman! ſay no more—ſay no more. Perverſeneſs and folly came in with the froſt, I believe, and pinches both old and young.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What ſteps can we take?—My anxiety for the ſweet young creature you have deſcribed to me—Pho! what does this trifling fellow do here?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p:
Hah, Mr. Bellair! they told me you were above, ſo I would come up. Very unlucky Miſs Archer is not at home! ſhe promis'd to introduce me to Lady Beauville—I hear ſhe has a grand route to-morrow, and I want to know her before, that I may be
invited—But I gueſs where Miſs Archer is, ſo I'll fly after her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Stay, Sir Marvel,—do you know where Miſs Archer is?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I gueſs—I gueſs. She uſed my carriage this morning, to run away with one Miſs Melville, whom Mr. Evergreen was going to carry into the country.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Heavens! my dear Sir Marvel, you give us life—Now, Doctor, what think ye of her breakfaſt in the moon?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Faith, I begin to ſuſpect that I may have breakfaſted there—I'm ſure my brain ſeems very cloudy. But where are they, Sir—where are they?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I can't tell, 'till I aſk my ſervants; but they can certainly tell where they carried them,—and that puts me in mind of a fine anecdote. About four centuries ago—
sp.stage: [with the air of beginning a long ſtory.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir Marvel, don't keep us here whole centuries—we muſt know inſtantly where thoſe ladies are.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Well, well, you ſhall;—I was only going to tell you, for you know you are not well read, Mr. Bellair, that Queen Dido of Carthagena—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, Doctor, preſcribe for him; he is moonſtruck too, depend on't. Sir, you muſt take us directly to the houſe where your carriage left the ladies.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pray do, good Sir, and then if you want bliſtering, or bleeding—

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: I want bliſtering! no, I am never ill, unleſs I'm near a phyſician. Well, come, I will take you, if you'll promiſe to have Queen Dido afterwards.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, every Queen in the Aeneid, with all my ſoul. Come along!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Pray take me too, and then I'll take the Princeſſes, and their maids of honour into the bargain.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'll take ye both—I'll take ye both. [Going out laſt.] What a happy thing it is to be of conſequence!

div.stage: Enter Miſs ARCHER, followed by Mrs. TOMSON.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I am much concerned that Miſs Melville has been indiſpoſed. Do you think ſhe is now aſleep?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TOMSON.
sp.p: I fancy ſo, Ma'am, for I left her on the ſopha—but I'll tell her—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Oh, on no account! let the ſweet girl repoſe a little;—her ſpirits, I am ſure, are much fatigued. If you'll give me that pamphlet I'll amuſe myſelf with it 'till ſhe wakes.

div.stage: [Mrs. TOMSON preſents a pamphlet and goes out. Miſs ARCHER tumbles over the leaves a ſhort time.]

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
Well, now, what ſignifies my attempting to read? my thoughts are ſo deranged, that Greek would be as pleaſant to me as Don Quixote. What a peculiar fate is mine! to receive a declaration of love from the only man whoſe lips I ever wiſh'd to hear it from, and yet, to be convey'd in ſuch a way, as to give me more pain than pleaſure. The air of ſincerity with which he made it, would have tranſported
me, had it not been poiſon'd by an unaccountable boldneſs and freedom.

div.stage: [Walks towards the book-caſe, and takes a book—CARLTON enters without ſeeing her—Throws himſelf on a chair, and his hat on a table—ſees her ſuddenly.]

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Zounds! Miſs Archer here again! Nay, then ſhe's my own—it would be ridiculous to affect diſpleaſure now. [Goes towards her, then ſtops.] No, faith—ſhe ſhall ſpeak firſt;—I'll be courted this time.
sp.stage: [Sits down again; Miſs ARCHER not obſerving him, he begins to ſing, to catch her attention.]
sp.p: "I've kiſs'd and I've prattled
"With fifty fair maids"—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: [Screams.] This is beyond all bearing!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: It would, indeed, if I ſuffered you to go;—No, no, dear creature! we ſhan't part now as we did in the morning:—I have juſt been at your guardian's, to tell you that I forgive all your ill behaviour to-day.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Forgive!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Aye, you may well wonder—'tis more than one in ten would do. Come, come—lower the ſcorn of that brow, and hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: I'll hear nothing, Sir, and I inſiſt on your leaving this houſe inſtantly.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—that's unreaſonable, conſidering where you are. But, come! I'll allow you half a dozen ill-humoured things, and then you ſhall attend to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
[Seeming to bite her tongue with vexation.] I will have my my own way in ſomething—I
won't ſay one ill-humour'd thing, though I feel a thouſand.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: A thouſand! Well, we have time before us, charmer; you ſhall have opportunities enough—every morning at breafaſt—every day at dinner—every—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: What can the monſter mean?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Mean! why to marry you, Petulance! to give you a right to plague me for ever. What an acquiſition, for a woman of ſpirit! Oh, I feel already the horrors of my future fate, but I am reſolv'd to go through it—I will go through it!

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: You imagine that the whimſicalneſs of this muſt excuſe its freedom, Mr. Carlton, but be aſſured—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Pho, pho, don't let us waſte time;—the plain Engliſh of our ſituation is this;—you are a coquette, and I am a man of the world; you would like to make me act like a fool, and I am determined to make you act like a woman of ſenſe—a proof that I am the beſt Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—very well!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: I admired you, the firſt moment I beheld you, but reſolv'd not to be made a dangler—which, if I had approach'd you in the common modes of courtſhip, would have inevitably followed.—I, therefore, took the road you have ſeen, and in conſequence you'll condeſcend to be happy, and make happy, a year or two ſooner than your coquetry would have allow'd.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: To be happy, and make happy!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p:
Yes; and that in ſpite of all thoſe pretty affected airs—they are but affected, charmer, you know,
for, at this moment, you feel that I have a kind of reſiſtleſs impudence about me, which you love for its novelty.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: If I thought it poſſible, Sir—The wretch reads my very heart.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nay, nothing but a wiſh to convince me of it, could bring you to my lodgings; you ſee the effects of carrying airs too far. You uſed me in the morning with ſuch barbarity, that your heart, hard as it is, was ſmote with the reflection, and then you run after me again to make it up. Oh, you dear commiſerating—

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: How dare you, Sir, inſinuate ſuch horrid things? Run after you!—ſeek you in your lodgings!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh dear! how a coquette may carry things!

div.stage: Enter haſtily Sir MARVEL, BELLAIR, and FEELOVE.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, oh, here they are! I am come to claim your promiſe—you muſt introduce me to Lady Beauville before to-morrow. Not to be at her route, would be to be and not to be—as Kemble ſays. Pray Ma'am have you ſeen Kemble?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where, Madam—where is Miſs Melville?

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Where is my niece?—where is Arabella Melville?

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Heyday! What is all this?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Oh, Carlton! how little did I ſuſpect that your lodgings—but there ſhe is!—
sp.stage: [Darting through the wing, followed by FEELOVE.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Are theſe Mr. Carlton's lodgings, then? 'Tis well his boldneſs has ſuch an excuſe.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that you did not know it?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Know it! Heaven and earth! how can you dare think that I did? I came to viſit Miſs Melville, whom I attended here this morning, without the moſt diſtant idea, that—Bleſs me! what an imputation has the intereſt I took in her welfare, ſubjected me to? I ſhall never ceaſe to regret the occaſion.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Nor I to bleſs it. How many tedious long months of hopes and fears, caprices and coquetry, have I been ſaved by it?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you are agreed! ſee the effect of a few good ſtanzas—'twas my poetry, Madam, not his, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: What poetry?

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, that little jeu d' eſprit, you know, which was publiſh'd yeſterday, about you.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: What! was not that Mr. Carlton's.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: No; he beg'd to paſs for the author, but it was my own compoſition entirely; without the aſſiſtance of any mortal man, whatever—deny it, Mr. Carlton, if you can.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: So thoſe wretched lines were yours? It was you who choſe to repreſent me to the public in ſo odious and hateful a light!—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: You had better have been quiet, Sir Marvel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, this is dev'liſh odd! when they paſſed for yours, ſhe never ſaid one word againſt them; and now they are mine, they are wretched, and odious, and hateful!

Heyday! Miſs Archer in Mr. Carlton's lodgings!
what, my dear creature, you are afraid of another fatire, and ſo are come to deprecate his wrath?

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: No, indeed, my dear creature,—but pray what brought you to Mr. Carlton's lodgings?

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Buſineſs, Ma'am, I aſſure you. Pray, Sir, ſtep this way, [to CARLTON.] Here are the verſes which you promis'd to get into the news-paper for me.—I have ſpent this whole day in poliſhing them.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My dear Madam, Sir Marvel has much more intereſt that way than I have.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, I'll get 'em in—I'll get 'em in, never fear. Let me ſee. [She endeavours to ſnatch them.] "Deſcription of Sir Marvel Muſhroom, or the Cripplegate Knight." What, Madam, me!—me!—am I a ſubject for a news-paper?

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: Yes;—or for a comedy, if I could write one. You are rich in folly, Sir Marvel, and would be a treaſure to the public.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Why, Madam, you will not dare—you will not dare. Oh, the licenſe given to theſe d—d newſpapers! I'll get a ſeat in parliament, in order to vote againſt the freedom of the preſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: So would all thoſe wretches feel, who tear the minds of the inoffenſive or the worthy—were they to be ſtretched on the rack, to which they ſo unfeelingly devote others.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: My charming creature, you muſt forgive Sir Marvel—I promiſed him that you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER
sp.p: [ſmiling]. Secure firſt your own forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: That ſweet ſmile ſecures it to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p:
No; you muſt earn it by long and
faithful ſervices. I will be a tyrant for two whole years, and you ſhall be the moſt humble and devoted of my ſlaves:—My caprice you ſhall allow to be reaſon, and my whims ſhall be your law.

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: For two months agreed! but not one hour longer. [Enter BELLAIR and ARABELLA.]—My dear Bellair, is this angel yours?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mine; and by a whimſical concurrence concealed in your lodgings. How much, Miſs Archer, am I indebted to you!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Indebted to her! No, 'tis to me. I wore the cloak, and I was pinch'd and pull'd whilſt ſhe eſcaped. One can neither have credit from one's verſes or one's good nature.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: So you really have forgiven him—Did I not foretell?

sp.speaker: ARAB.
sp.p: Oh, goodneſs! there was nothing to forgive—You can't think how innocent he is.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: The devil! What, Bellair found her firſt! Come, Sir, give up my Bell!

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Your Bell! No, no, you muſt go for your bell to another ſteeple, my old friend—This little ſilver-toned thing would never be heard on the Welch mountains; and ſo I have given it to him.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: To him! You muſt joke, Doctor. You cannot mean to beſtow your niece on a poor wretch, the victim, as you have often called him, of atrophy and diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: There, d'ye ſee!—again!—again! Sir, you libel me, and, Sir—

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: Libel ye! Why you libel yourſelf.—That's your poor invalid—the dying man. You'll never be able to ſtand the laugh, if you give your niece to him. Come, come, Doctor, give me the—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir I have received Miſs Melville from this gentleman, who will be ſo generous as to pardon the innocent ſtratagems of love.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Stratagems! What then—what then, are you the—the—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You know I told you, Doctor, that I had an irreſiſtable fancy, that I ſhould live and become a ſtout, hale young fellow. I determined not to oppoſe my odd fancy, as the old lady did her's.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE
sp.p: Ho—h! So, Sir, you had the—the impudence—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I had the impudence to live—But pray pardon it! I will do any thing but die—I'll ſwallow all the gums, woods, herbs, and funguſes, in your medicopeia, to make it up.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: You had better, Sir—I ſay, you had better—Oh!

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Stay, good Sir! you muſt be reconciled.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Dear Doctor, be but reconciled, I'll advertiſe my death, change my name, and fight every man who dares tell me I am alive.

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: He muſt not be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: He can't reſiſt us.—I'll make love to him. Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: And I'll let him preſcribe for me—Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: Miſs JUV.
sp.p: And I'll write the epithalamium—Dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: He ſhall reſiſt you—He ſhall not be reconciled.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Here, Mr. Bellair [giving his hand] I will be reconciled, though—excuſe me!—I ſhould rather you were dead.—However, I will be reconciled.

sp.speaker: EVEGR.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you will, will ye? You ſhall repent it. Bellair, though I ſhall never ſpeak to you more, I'll tell you at parting that her fortune is thirty thouſand pounds—Remember, thirty. There, Doctor, that has cut you ſhort of ten or fifteen thouſand, I know; ſo your joke has coſt as much as mine.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: Sir, you are—Sir, my reſentment for this uſage—

sp.speaker: CARL.
sp.p: Oh, gentlemen, you muſt not—you muſt not quarrel.

sp.speaker: MARV.
sp.p: Oh, yes, let 'em quarrel, pray, if they have a fancy for it. Doctor, I'll carry your challenge—What are your weapons?

sp.speaker: EVERG.
sp.p: His preſcriptions—He can kill with nothing elſe; he's harmleſs in all other reſpects.

sp.speaker: FEELOVE.
sp.p: And you are harmleſs in nothing but your wit;—the point of that is never felt.

sp.speaker: Miſs ARCHER.
sp.p: Come, come, ſince your anger expends itſelf in words, there are hopes of its ſubſiding; and that the happineſs we are preparing to enjoy, will neither be clouded by your diſpleaſure; nor by that of our beſt friends.
sp.l: To them we bend, ſubmiſſive to their laws,

lg.l: I SPEAK the Epilogue! Lud, how they teaze one!
They write ſo dull—ſo—ſeldom they can pleaſe one:
I never read 'em—Well—I'll truſt to chance,
And now before 'em, frighten'd, I'll advance.
Ladies and Gents—behold—that is—our play
We hope will—Lud, I don't know what to ſay!
To entertain the cit, the belle, the beau,
With India—Stamps—or, Race at Fontainbleau.
In days of yore—bright days, with conqueſt crown'd!
The French we beat, and beat on their own ground;
We conquer ſtill by valour or by cunning,
On their own ground we beat'em now—in running.
I'll try, as Mercury did, a ſmall deception,
It may ſecure, at leaſt, a good reception.—
How do I look? If I can truſt my glaſs,
I think for Venus I may ſafely paſs;
(I'm ſure found out to ſay I'm any other;)
No more Miſs Archer now—the archer's mother!
Nay, never wonder, doubt, nor ſtart, nor ſtare,
Don't you perceive the Goddeſs in my air?
Yon low'ring brow ſays, No—Well!—if you doubt me,
I'll drop the Goddeſs,—here's enough without me:
Each ſcarlet Mars above, though e'er ſo dainty,
May leer around—there's Venus's in plenty;
Or aim his glaſs beneath, upon the pit,
He'll ſee his Venus by her Vulcan ſit:
There Bacchus woos his Venus all divine!
He nectar aſks—but ſhe—a pint of wine!
And you can never want the Queen of Love,
I ſpeak to you, ye roaring Gods above;—
Momus is ſurely there, from all this racket,
Yonder he ſits—he's in a ſailor's jacket;
Thrice happy God, who lives but in a joke!
His Venus laughs, too—in her hat and cloak.
Where have I got to?—Lud, how glib my tongue!
Am I Miſs Archer, Venus, or Miſs Younge?
Be what I will, among my friends I rank ye,
Applaud Miſs Archer, and Miſs Younge ſhall thank ye.

div.head: Of the PUBLISHER may be had, By the ſame AUTHOR,

list.item: WHICH IS THE MAN? a Comedy.
A BOLD STROKE FOR A HUSBAND, a Comedy.
THE MAID OF ARRAGON, a Poem.
